editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The fair maid of the exchange: with the pleasant humours of the cripple of Fanchurch.
Very delectable, and full of mirth.
London printed for Henry Rockit, and are to be sold at the shop in the poultry under the dial. 1607.

div.head: Eleven may easily act this comedy.

list.item: Berry an old man for one.
Flower an humorous old man for one.
Ferdin. Gold. gent. and wood. for one.
Bowdler an humorous gallant. for one.
Phillis the fair maid for one.

lg.l: The humble sock that true comedians were,
Our muse hath donned, and to your fav'ring eyes,
In lowest plainsong doth herself appear,
Borrowing no colours from a quaint disguise:
If your fair favours cause her spirit to rise,
She to the highest pitch her wings shall rear,
And proud cothurnic action shall devise,
To win your sweet applause she deems so dear.
Meanwhile shore up our tender pamping twig,
That yet on humble ground doth lowly lie:
Your favours sunshine guilding once this sprig,
It may yield nectar for the gods on high:
Though our invention lame, imperfect be,
Yet give the cripple alms for charity.

div.head: Â¶ The fair maid of the exchange.
Scene. i.
div.l: E'en now the welcome twilight doth salute
Th'approaching night clad in black sable weeds.
Black as my thoughts, that harbour naught but death,
Thefts, murders, rapes and such like damned acts,
The infant babes to whom my soul is nurse:
Bodeth some good, the weather's fair and dry.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: My scarlet-hearted scarlet, gallant blood,
Whose bloody deeds are worthy memory
Of after ages, let me embrace thee: so,
So, now methinks I fold a richer gem,
Than wealthy India can afford to Spain:
There lies my treasure, and within thy arms
Security that never breedeth harms.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Brave resolution, I am proud to see
So sweet a graft upon a wormwood tree,
Whose juice is gall, but yet the fruit most rare:
Who wreaks the tree, if that the fruit be fair?
Therefore resolve, if we a booty get,
It boots not whence, from whom, when, where, or what.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: Well (God forgive us) here let's take our stands,
We must have gold although we have no lands.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Stay Ursula, have you those suits of ruffs,
Those stomachers, and that fine piece of lawn,
Marked with the letters c c. and s.

sp.speaker: Ursula.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If your forgetfulness cause any defect,
You're like to pay for't, therefore look unto it.

sp.speaker: Vrsu.
sp.l: I would our journey had as safe an end,
As I am sure my lady's ruffs are here,
And other wares which she bespoke of you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis good; but stay, give me thy hand my girl,
'Tis somewhat dark, come, let us help each other:
She passed her word one of her gentlemen
Should meet us at the bridge, and that's not far,
I muse they are not come, I do assure thee,
Were I not much beholding to her ladyship
For many kindnesses: Mile-end, should stand
This gloomy night unvisited for us.
But come, methinks I may discern the bridge.
And see a man or two, in very deed
Her word, her love and all is honourable.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: A prize young scarlet, o, a gallant prize,
And we are pirates that will seize the same
To our own uses.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: But hold man, not too fast:
As far as I can gather by their words,
They take us for my lady's gentlemen,
Who as it seems should meet them on their way,
Then if thou sayest the word we'll seem those men,
And by those means withdraw them from their way.
Where we may rifle them of what they carry,
I mean, both goods, and their virginity.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: 'Tis well advised, but scarlet, give me leave
To play the gentleman and welcome them.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Enjoy thy wish.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: Welcome you sacred stars,
That add bright glory to the sable night.

sp.speaker: Scarl.
sp.l: Excellent, by heaven.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: I am sorry your beauty's so discomfited,
Treading so many tedious weary steps,
And we not present to associate you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O, blessed Bobbington.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir, I do thank you for this taken pains,
That as your worthy lady promised me,
We now enjoy your wished company.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: She's thine own boy, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: And I am proud, too proud of this employment,
Come m. scarlet take you that pretty sweet,
You see my lady's care; she promised one
But hath sent two.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis honourably done.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: This is your way.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That way, alas sir no.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: Come, it is: nay than it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What mean you gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Vrsu.
sp.l: O he will rob me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Look to the box Ursula.

sp.speaker: Phil. and Vrsu.
sp.l: Help, help, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Now you supporters of decrepit youth,
That mount this substance twixt fair heaven and earth,
Be strong to bear that huge deformity,
And be my hands as nimble to direct them,
As your desires to waft me hence to London.

sp.speaker: Phil. and Vrsu.
sp.l: Help, help, he'll ravish me.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: My thinks I hear the sound of ravishment.

sp.speaker: Phil. and Vrsu.
sp.l: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Marry and will, knew I but where, and how.
What do I see?
Thieves full of lust beset virginity!
Now stir thee cripple, and of thy four legs
Make use of one, to do a virgin good:
Hence ravening curs: what, are you at a prey?
Will nothing satisfy your greedy chaps
But virgin's flesh? I'll teach you prey on carrion,Fight and beat them away.
Pack damned ravishers, hence villains.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thanks, honest friend, who from the gates of death
Hath set our virgin souls at liberty.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Give God the glory that gave me the power.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I do, kind sir, and think myself much bound
To him above, to thee that treads this ground,
And for this aid, I'll ever honour thee;
My honour you have saved redeemed it home:
Which were't not done, by this time had been gone.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Hereafter more of this; but tell me now
The cause of these events, the effect, and how.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'll tell you sir; but let us leave this place,
And onward on our way.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: It shall be so, see where they walk along,
I'll cross the other way and meet them full,
Keep thou this way, and when thou hearst us chat,
Come thou behind him snatch away his crutches,
And than thou knowest he needs must fall to ground,
And what shall follow leave the rest to me. Exit. Bobb.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: About it then.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: I'faith she is an honourable lady,
And I much wonder that her ladyship
Gives entertain to such bad men as these.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: Stand thou that hast more legs than nature gave thee.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Mongrel, I'll choose.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Then go to sir, you shall.

sp.speaker: All, all.
sp.l: Murder murder.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Stay there my horse:
Whence comes this echo of extremity?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: What do I hear, a virgin call for help?
Hands off damned villains, or by heaven I swear,
I'll send you all to hell. Fight and drive them away.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Hold, forbear.
I came in rescue of virginity.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He did, he did, and freed us once from thrall.
But now the second time they wrought his fall.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Now you distressed objects, do you tell
Upon what mount of woe your sorrows dwell.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: First get we hence away, and as we go,
Kind gentleman, our fortunes you shall know.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Thanks worthy sir, may but the cripple be,
Of power to gratify this courtesy,
I then shall think the heaven's favour me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No more now for god's sake, let us hence.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: If I do live, your love I'll recompense. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Now for my truelove's handkercher; these flowers
Are pretty toys, are very pretty toys:
Oh but methinks the Peascod would do better,
The Peascod and the blossom, wonderful!
Now as I live, I'll surely have it so.
Some maids will choose the gillyflower, some the rose,
Because their sweet cents do delight the nose,
But very fools they are in my opinion,
The very worst being drawn by cunning art,
Seems in the eye as pleasant to the heart.
But here's the question, whether my love or no
Will seem content? Ay, there the game doth go:
And yet I'll pawn my head he will applaud
The Peascod and the flower, my pretty choice.
For what is he loving a thing in heart,
Loves not the counterfeit, though made by art?
I cannot tell how others fancy stand,
But I rejoice sometime to take in hand,
The simile of that I love; and I protest,
That pretty peascod likes my humour best.
But I'll unto the drawers, he'll counsel me,
Here is his shop: alas, what shall I do?
He's not within, now all my labour's lost,
See, see, how forward love is ever crossed,
But stay, what gallant's this?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: A plague on this drawer, he's never at home:
Good morrow sweetheart, tell me, how thou dost?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Upon what acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: That's all one, once I love thee, give me thy hand and say, amen.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Hands off, sir knave, and wear it for a favour.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: What? dost thou mean thy love pretty fool?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: No fool, the knave, oh gross;
A gentleman and of so shallow wit!

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: I know thou camest to the drawer.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: How then?

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Am not I the properer man?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Yes, to make an ass on.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Will you get up and ride?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: No, I'll lackey by his side, and whip the ass.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Come, come, leave your jesting, I shall put you down.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: With that face! away you want-wit.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: By this hand, I shall.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: By the ass-head you shall not.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Go to, you are a woman.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Come, come, ye are a man.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: I have seen as fair.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: I have heard as wise.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: As fair as Mall Berry.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: As wise as young Bowdler.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: As m. Bowdler.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Hoida; come up.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Go thou down then.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: No good ass, bate an ace of that.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What m. Bowdler, will it ne'er be otherwise?
Still, still a hunting, every day wenching?

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Faith sir, the modest behaviour of this gentlewoman,
Hath insinuated my company.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Lord, how eloquence flows in this gentleman!

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Faith, I shall put you down in talk, you were best to yield.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: No sir, I will hold out as long as I may,
Though in the end you bear the fool away.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Mean you by me? you gull me not?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: No by this night, not I.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: For if you did, I would intoxicate my head.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Yea, I dare sware you'll go a fool to bed.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Mean you by me? you gull me not?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, I dare swear the gentlewoman means well.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: And so I do indeed, himself can tell:
But this it is, speak maidens what they will,
Men are so captious they'll ever construe ill.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: To her sir, to her, I dare sware she loves you.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Well then fair mall, you love me as you say.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: I never made you promise, did I, I pray?

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: All in good time you will do, else you lie,
Will you not?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: No forsooth not I.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Barnard, she gulls me still.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: 'Tis but your misconceit, try her again:
You know by course all women must be coy;
To her again, than she may happily yield.
Not I, in faith.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Then mine shall be the field:
Wisdom, adieu, once more faint heart farewell;
Yet if thou seest the drawer, I prithee tell him,
Mall Berry hath more work for him to do;
And for yourself, learn this when you do woe,
Arm you with courage, and with good take heed,
For he that spares to speak must spare to speed,
And so farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Call her again, Barnard.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: She's too swift for me:
Why this is the right course of gullery,
What did you mean having so fair an aim
So fondly to let slip so fair a game?
Bowdler become a man for maids will stand,
And then strike home, art thou not young and lusty,
The minion of delight, fair from thy birth,
Adonis' playfere, and the pride of earth?

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: I know it, but a kind of honest blood
Tilts in my loins, with wanton appetites,
She bade me do a message to the drawer,
and I will do it; there will come a day,
When Humphrey Bowdler, will keep holiday,
Than Mall look to yourself, see that you be sped,
Or by this light I'll have your maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Larn.
sp.l: Spoken like a gallant, spoken like a gentleman, spoken like yourself:
Now do I see some sparks of manhood in you,
Keep in that key, keep in the self same song,
I'll gauge my head you'll have her love ere long. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Wilt thou not tell me (Brother Ferdinand)
Now by this light I'll haunt thee like a sprite,
Until I know whence springs this melancholy.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: O brother!
Thou art too young to reach the depth of grief,
That is immured within my hearts deep closet,
A thousand sighs keep daily centinel,
That beat like whirlwinds all my comfort back,
As many sobs guard my distressed heart,
That no relief comes near to aid my soul,
Millions of woes like bands of armed men,
Stop up the passage of my sweet relief:
And art thou then persuaded that thy words,
Can any comfort to my soul afford?
No, no, good Frank, dear brother then forbear,
Unless with grief in me you'll take a share.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Grief me no griefs, but tell me what it is
Makes my (Sweet Ferdinand) thus passionate:
I'll conjure grief, if grief be such an evil,
In spite of fortune, fates, or any devil.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Wilt thou not leave me to myself alone?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Brother, you know my mind,
If you will leave your dumpish melancholy,
And like myself banish that puling humour,
Or satisfy my expectation,
By telling whence your sorrow doth proceed
I will not only cease to trouble you,
But like a true skilful physician,
Seek all good means for your recovery.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Well brother, you have much importuned me,
And for the confidence I have in you,
That you'll prove secret, I will now unfold,
The load of care that presseth down my soul:
Know then good Frank, love is the cause hereof.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: How, love! why what's that love?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: A child, a little little boy that's blind.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: And be o'ercome by him! plagued by him!
Driven into dumps by him! put down by a boy!
Mastered by love! O, I am mad for anger:
By a boy! is there no rosemary and bays in England
To whip the ape? by a boy!

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Ay, such a boy as thou canst never see,
And yet ere long mayst feel his tyranny:
He's not visible, yet aims at the heart,
Woe be to those that feel his wounding dart;
And one of them I am: wounded so deep,
That in my passions I no mean can keep:
Unhappy time, woe to that dismal hour,
When love did wound me with fair Phillis flower:
Oh Phillis, Phillis; of flowers sweetest flower,
That ever garnished any princely bower:
Farewell, farewell, my woes will never remove,
Till I enjoy fair Phillis for my love. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: What's here, Phillis and love, and love and Phillis:
I have seen Phillis, and have heard of love;
I will see Phillis, and will hear of love:
But neither Phillis, nor the power of love,
Shall make me bondslave to a woman's beck.
Who's here, my second brother malcontent?
I'll stand aside and note his passions.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O love, that I had never known thy power.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: More lovers yet! what the devil is this love?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: That these my wand'ring eyes had kept their stay;
That I myself had still been like myself;
That my poor heart had never felt the wound,
Whose anguish keeps me in a deadly sound:
O how deluding dreams this night o'erpast,
Drenched my sad soul in pleasures floating sea!
Methought I clasped my love within my arms,
And circling her, saved her from threatening harms;
Methought there came an hundred in an hour
That sought to rob me of my sweetest flower:
But like a champion I did keep her still
Within this circle, free from every ill:
But when I waked and missed my Phillis there,
All my sweet joys converted into fear.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: What brother Anthony, at prayers so hard?
Tell me what saint it is thou invocates?
Is it a male, or female? howsoever,
God bless thee brother, thou'rt in a good mind,
But now I remember me, thy saint is blind.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: How, blind?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I brother, blind, I heard thee talk of love,
And love is blind they say.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I would it were as blind as ebon night,
That love had never hit my heart so right;
But what is love in your opinion?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: A voluntary motion of delight,
Touching the superficies of the soul;
A substance less divine then is the soul,
Yet more than any other power in man
Is that which loves, yet neither is enforced,
Nor doth enforce the heart of man to love:
Which motion as it unbeseems a man,
So by the soul and reason which adorn,
The life of man it is extinguished,
Even at his pleasure that it doth possess.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Thus may the freeman jest at manacles,
The fur-clad citizen laugh at a storm,
The swarthy Moor diving to gather pearl,
challenge the scalding ardour of the sun;
And aged Nestor sitting in his tent,
May term wounds sport, and war but merriment.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: 'Tis true, fore God it is, and now methinks ,
My heart begins to pity hearts in love:
Say once more, Anthony, tell me thy griefs,
Let me have feeling of my passion,
Possess me deeply of thy melting state,
And thou shalt see.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: That thou wilt pity me,

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: No by my troth, if every tale of love,
Or love itself, or fool-bewitching beauty,
Make me cross-arm myself; study ay-mees;
Defy my hatband; tread beneath my feet
Shoestrings and garters; practise in my glass
Distressed looks, and dry my liver up,
With sighs enough to win an argosy.
If ever I turn thus fantastical,
Love plague me, never pity me at all.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Yonder she comes that holds me prisoner.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: What? Phillis, the fair maid of the exchange?
Is she god Cupid's judge over men's hearts?
Brother, I'll have one veny with her tongue,
To breathe my wit, and jest at passion:
By your leave mistress flower.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your rude behaviour scarce offers you welcome.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I prithee tell me Phillis, I hear say,
Thou keepest love captive in thy maiden thoughts.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That is a thought beyond your reach to know.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: But shall I know it?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: On what acquaintance? then might you deem me fond,
If (As you say) love be at my command.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: May not your friend command as great a matter?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'll know him well first, for that friend may flatter.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Why, I hope you know me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That's a question.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Well, if you do not, you shall before I stir.
Know you yonder lump of melancholy,
Yonder bundle of sighs yonder wad of groans,
The same and I were chickens of one brood,
And if you know him, as I am sure you do,
Being his brother, you needs must know me too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I partly have a guess of yonder gentleman,
His name is master Golding as I take it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Golding I am, and thine sweet fair I am,
And yet not thine, but a most wretched man,
Thou knowest my cause of grief, my wound of woe:
And knowing it, why wilt thou see it so?
Put salves of comfort to my grief's unrest,
So mayst thou heal my sore of heaviness.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Hark you fair maid, are you a surgeon?
I prithee give my brother Anthony
Somewhat to heal the love sore of his mind,
And yet 'tis pity that he should have help:
A man as free as air, or the sun's rays,
As boundless in his function as the heavens,
The male and better part of flesh and blood,
In whom was powered the quintessence of reason,
To wrong the adoration of his maker,
By worshipping a wanton female skirt,
And making love his idol: fie dotard, fie,
I am ashamed of this apostasy,
I'll talk with her to hinder his complaints.
Phillis, a word in private ere you go,
I love ye sweet.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sour, it may be so.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Sour, and sweet; faith that doth scarce agree.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Two contraries, and so be we.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A plague on this courting, come, we'll make an end.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am sorry for it since you seem my friend.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Ay, but thou canst not weep.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then had I a hard heart.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: How say you? come brother, now to your part.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: At your direction: no, this merry glee,
(Good brother) sorts not with my melancholy,
Love covets private conference, so my sorrow,
Craveth your absence which I fain would borrow.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: No marvel than we say that love is blind,
If it still revel in obscurity,
I will depart I will not hinder love,
I'll wash my hands fare well sweet turtle dove. Exit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'faith your brother is a proper man.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: What's your will with me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Even what you please.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Did you not call me back?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Not, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: No, 'sblood somewhat did, farewell, farewell.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He is a very very proper man.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I am in haste pray urge me not to stay.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The man doth dote pray God he hits his way.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Fore God there's not a maid in all this town,
Should sooner win me, but my business calls me,
Give me thy hand, next time I meet with thee,
Lesser entreaty shall woo my company.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'faith i'faith.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I'faith, this was the hand, what means my blood,
Do I not blush, nor look extremely pale?
Is not my head a fire, my eyes nor heart?
Ha, art thou here? I feel thee love i'faith,
By this light, well via farewell, farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Now he is gone, and we in private talk,
Say, wilt thou grant me love, wilt thou be mine?
For all the interest in my love is thine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your brother Ferdinand hath vowed as much,
Nam more, he swears what man soe'er he be,
Presumes to be corrival in his love,
He will revenge it as an injury,
And clothe the thief in basest obloquy.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Ay, is my brother my competitor?
I'll court my love and will solicit thee,
Were Ferdinand himself in company.
What sayest thou to my suit?

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: Time may do much, what I intend to do
I mean to pause upon.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let it be so;
If that my brother's hindrance be all,
I'll have thy love though by my brother's fall.Exit

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Two brothers drowned in love, I and the third
For all his outward habit of neglect,
If I judge rightly if I did not dream,
Hath dipped his foot too in love's scalding stream.
Well, let them plead and perish if they will;
Cripple, my heart is thine, and shall be still. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: I am not well, and yet I am not ill,
I am, what am I? not in love I hope?
sp.p:
In love! let me examine myself, who should I love? who did I last converse with, with Phillis: why should I love Phillis? is she fair? faith so so: her forehead is pretty, somewhat resembling the forehead of the sign of the maiden head in, etc. What's her hair? faith to Bandora wiars, there's not the like simile: is it likely yet that I am in love? What's next? her cheeks, they have a reasonable scarlet, never a dyer's daughter in the town goes beyond her. Well, yet I am not in love. Nay, she hath a mole in her cheek too: Venus' mole was not more natural; but what of that, I am Adonis, and will not love. Good Venus pardon me. Let us descend: her chin, oh Helen, Helen, where's your dimple Helen? it was your dimple that bewitched Paris, and without your dimple I will not love you Helen, no, yet I am safe. Her hand, lets handle that, I saw her hand, and it was lily white, I touched her palm, and it was soft and smooth: and then what then? her hand did then bewitch me, I shall be in love now out of hand. In love! shall I that ever yet have profaned love, now fall to worship him? Shall I that have jested at lovers sighs now raise whirl winds? shall I that have flouted ay-mees once a quarter, now practise ay-mees every minute? shall I defy hatbands, and tread garters and shoestrings under my feet? shall I fall to falling bands and be a ruffian no longer? I must; I am now liege man to Cupid, and have read all these informations in his book of statutes, the first chapter, page millesimo nono, therefore, hatband avaunt, ruff regard your
self, garters adieu, shoestrings so and so; I am a poor enamorate, and enforced with the poet to say, love o'ercomes all, and I that love obey. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.l: Now afore God a very good conceit,
But too much sleep hath over taken me,
The night hath played the swift-foot runaway:
A good conceit, a very good conceit,
What fiddle, arise fiddle, fiddle I say.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Here's a fiddling indeed, I think your tongue be made of nothing but fiddlestrings, I hope the fiddle must have some rest as well as the fiddlestick: well crowd, what say you to fiddle now?

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Fiddle, it is a very good conceit.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: It is indeed, master.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: What dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: To go to bed again sir.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: No, fiddle, that were no good conceit fiddle,

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: What a fiddling do you keep, are you not ashamed to make such music; I hope sir, you will christen me anew shortly, for you have so worn this name, that never a wench in all the town but will scorn to dance after my fiddle.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Well fiddle, thou art an honest fellow.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: That's more than you know, master.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: I'll swear for thee fiddle.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: You'll be damned then, master.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: I love thee fiddle.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I had rather your daughter loved me,

sp.speaker: Elow,
sp.p: 'Tis a rare conceit i'faith.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I hold with you master, if my young mistress would like so well of my music, that she would dance after nobody's instrument but mine.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: No fiddle, that were no good conceit.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: A shame on you, I thought you would not hear on that side

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: Fiddle, thou toldst me, m. Golding was in love with my daughter.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: True, master; therein you say well.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.p: And he entreats me to meet him at the star in cheap, to talk concerning the match.

sp.speaker: Fiddle
sp.p: True still master.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And I have sent for my neighbour m. Berry to bear me company,

sp.speaker: Fiddle
sp.p: True, all this is most natural truth.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And now fiddle, I am going on my way.

sp.speaker: Fiddle
sp.p: Nay that's a lie, that hath marred all, was your conceit so tired you could tell troth no longer?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why fiddle, are we not going?

sp.speaker: Fiddle
sp.p: No indeed sir, we are not, we stand still, your conceit failed in that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Fore God 'tis true, I am not ready yet: what's he?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: By your leave sir, I would crave a word in secret sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: At your pleasure, here's none but my man fiddle,

sp.speaker: Fiddle
sp.p: Ay sir, master fiddle is my name, sir Laurence Syro was my father.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Sir, this is my business, my name is racket, I have a ship of my own upon the river.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: By your leave sir, captain racket is your name.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Some call me so indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: It is a good conceit, I pray proceed.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Sir, I am now bound to sea, and wanting some money for the better furnishing of my wants.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: O, you would borrow money of me.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: That's my suit indeed.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: That's no good conceit.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Nam, hear me sir, if you will supply me with ten pound till my return from Barbary, I will leave in your hands a diamond of greater value than the money.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: A diamond, is it a diamond, or but a counterfet?
Fiddle, my spectacles.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: 'Tis right, I assure you sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Then 'tis a good conceit: my spectacles.

sp.speaker: Fiddle
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Where sir?

sp.speaker: Fiddle
sp.l: You cannot see master, but I can.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O 'tis good, it is a good conceit: well sir, ten pound,
You are content if at three months end,
you bring me not ten pound in English coin,
This diamond shall be my proper own.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: I am sir, shall I receive the money now?

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.l: Ay, here it is, and 'tis a good conceit.
Will you go near sir? Fiddle, make him drink.

sp.speaker: Fiddle
sp.l: Will you approach cavaliero, if I speak not in season, 'tis because I was never in the salt country, where you sea captains use to march.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: You are very eloquent sir, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Fiddle
sp.l: Let me alone then for leading my men.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: A diamond worth forty for ten pound,
If he return not safe from Barbary,
'Tis good, a very good conceit. Enter m. Berry.

sp.speaker: Berry
sp.l: By your leave master flower.

sp.speaker: Flow.
sp.l: Welcome good master berry, I was bold to entreat your company to speak with a friend of mine,
It is some trouble, but the conceit is good.

sp.speaker: Berry
sp.l: No trouble at all sir, shall we be going?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: With all my heart sir, and as we go,
I'll tell you my conceit, come master Berry. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter at one door Cripple, at the other Bowdler.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Well met my dear bundle of rue, well met.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: As much to thee my humorous blossom.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: A plague on thee for a dog, have I found thee? I hate thee not, and yet by this hand I could find in my heart: but sirrah, crutch, I was encountered.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: Who became your bail?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Ye filthy dog, I was encountered by a wench I say.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: In a wench's counter! I thought no less: what sirrah didst thou lie in the knight's ward, or on the master's side?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Neither, neither i'faith.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: Where then, in the hole?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: By this hand Cripple I'll bombast thee!

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: My crutch you mean for wearing out my clothes.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p:
Thy nose dog, thy nose, a plague on thee, I care not for thee, and yet I cannot choose but love thee.
Sirrah, mall Berry was here about work thou hast of hers, hadst thou been here to have heard how I spurred the wench with incantations, thou wouldst have given me the praise for a jester.

sp.speaker: Cripple
sp.p: True master Bowdler, I yield it you, I hold you for the absolut'st jester; oh mistake me not, I mean to jest upon, a juggling gull, a profound seeing man of shallow wit, that Europe, na the world I think affords.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Well, thou art a Jew sirrah, I'll cut out that venomous tongue of thine one of these days.

sp.speaker: Cripple
sp.p: Do it in time, or I'll crush the heart of thy wit till I have strained forth thy infectious humour to a drop i'faith.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Here comes my amorous vessel, I'll board her i'faith: well encountered Mall, how dost thou wench, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: What's that to you sir?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Why I ask thee in kindness.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why then in kindness you are a fool for asking.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Is the fool your livery?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Not so, for then you wearing that livery, would term yourself my fool.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Meaning me? you gull me not, if you do:

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: O vile! I would take you down.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Alas it wants wit, his wit is too narrow.

sp.speaker: Bowdler
sp.p: I'll stretch my wit but I will take you down.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How, upon the tenters? indeed if the whole piece were so stretched, and very well beaten with a yard of reformation, no doubt it would grow to a goodly breadth.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: By this hand.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Away you ass, hinder not my business.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: Finely put off wench i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: By your leave master drawer.

sp.speaker: Cripple
sp.p: Welcome mistress Berry, I have been mindful of your work.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Is it done?

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: Yes, and here it is.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Here is your money.
Cripple, ere long I'll visit thee again,
I have some ruffs and stomachers to draw.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: At your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: By thy leave Mall, a word.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Away you bundle of nothing, away. Exit Mal.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: She hath a wit as sharp as her needle.

sp.speaker: Bowdler
sp.p: Alas, myself have been her whetstone with my conference in th'exchange any time these many years.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: In th'exchange! I have walked with thee there, before the visitation of my legs, and my expense in timber, at the least a hundred times, and never heard thee speak to a wench.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: That's a lie, thou wert by when I bought these gloves of a wench.

sp.speaker: Cripple.
sp.p: That's true, they cost thee an English shilling at a word, marry it follows in the text, that your shilling proved but a harper, and thou wert shamefully arraigned for it.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Good, but I excused myself.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: True, that thou thoughtst it had been a shilling, marry thou hadst never another, nor so much as a shilling more to change it. Thou talk in th'exchange!

sp.speaker: Bowdler
sp.p: Indeed my best gift is in the morning when the maids visit my chamber, with such necessaries as I usually buy of them.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: O thou art one of those, that if an honest maid be sent to thy chamber with her mistress goods, and return as honest and chaste as the moon: sirrah, you are one of those that will slander the poor wenches, by speaking liberally of their proneness to love; and withal, brag how cheap you have bought their ware metaphorically, when indeed they depart as honest as they came thither, and leave you all the day after to sigh at the sight of an ill bargain.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.p: When wilt thou spit out this serpent's tongue of thine?

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: When wilt thou cast off this antic garment of ostentation? do it, do it, or by the lord I will impress thy vanities, and so anatomize the very bowels of thy absurdities, that all the world shall take notice of thee for a fool, and shun thee as the pox or the pestilence.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: News, news, news.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Sweet rogue, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: By Jesu the rarest dancing in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Sweet rascal, where, oh do not kill my soul
With such delays, tell me kind rogue, oh tell me where it is.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: At a wedding in gracious street.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Come, come, away, I long to see the man
In dancing art that does more than I can.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Than you sir! he lives not.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Why I did understand thee so.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You only excepted, the world besides
Cannot afford more exquisite dancers
Than are now capering in that bridal house.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: I will behold them, come crutch, thou shalt with us.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Down dog, I'll have thy company.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: I have business.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: By this hand thou shalt go with us.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: By this leg I will not.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: A lame oath, never stand to that.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: By this crutch but I will.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Come, you lose time, supper is done long since,
And they are now a dancing.

sp.speaker: Berry
sp.l: Stay fiddle with thy torch, gentlemen, good even.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: Master Berry!

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Master Berry, I wish you well sir: master fiddle I am yours for a congee.

sp.speaker: Fiddle
sp.l: After the French salutation I am yours for the like courtesy.

sp.speaker: Berry
sp.l: Master Barnard, tomorrow is your day
Of payment sir, I mean the hundred pound,
For which I have your bond, I know 'tis sure,
You will not break an hour; then if you please
To come to dinner sir, you shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: Sir, I did mean to visit you at home,
Not to pay down the money, but entreat
too months forbearance.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: How! forbear my money?
Your reason, why I should forbear my own?

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: You know at first the debt was none of mine,
I was a surety, not the principal:
Besides, the money that was borrowed
Miscarried in the venture; my friend died,
And once already have you prisoned me,
To my great charge, almost my overthrow,
And somewhat raised the debt by that advantage:
These things considered, you may well forbear
For two months space, so small a sum as this.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: How! I may forbear; sir, I have need of money:
I may indeed sit moneyless at home,
And let you walk abroad spending my coin.
This I may do, but sir you know my mind,
If you do break your day, assure yourself,
That I will take the forfeit of your bond.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: The forfeit of his bond!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ay sir, the forfeit; 'tis no charity
To favour you that live like libertines:
Here's a crew!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A crew; what crew?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: A crew of unthrifts, careless dissolutes,
Licentious prodigals, vild tavern-tracers.
Night watching money-wasters, what should I call ye?
O I want words for to define you rightly;
But this I know, London never fostered such
As Barnard, Bowdler, and this paltry crutch.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: And you want words sirrah, I'll teach thee words;
Thou shouldst have come to every one of us
As thus: thou wretch, thou miser thou vild slave
And drudge to money, bondman to thy wealth,
Apprentice to a penny, thou that hoards up
The fry of silver pence and halfpennies,
With show of charity to give the poor,
But puttest them to increase, where in short time
They grow a child's part, or a daughter's portion.
Thou that invent'st new clauses for a bond
To cousin simple plainness: oh not a dragon,
No, nor the devil's fangs are half so cruel
As are thy claws; thus, thus thou shouldst have railed:
The forfeit of his bond, oh I could spit
My heart into his face; thou bloodhound that dost hunt
The dear, dear life of noble gentry.

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.l: Cripple, 'tis known I am an honest man;
But for thy words, Barnard shall fare the worse:
As for thyself.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Who he sir, never regard him, I know the vildest thing by him, oh 'tis abominable!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Dost thou so fiddle, speak, hold, take thou that speak of his shame, speak freely, I'll protect thee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I tell you sir, 'twill make your hair to stand on end as stiff as a rubbing-brush, to hear his villainies.
What's this you have given me?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: A shilling fiddle.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Have you any skill in arithmetic?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why dost thou ask?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Sir, I would have you to multiply; could you not make this one shilling two or three? I would not be known to beg, but if out of your cunning you can do this trick of multiplication, I shall speak the better.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O there's another shilling for thee, now let me hear what villainies thou canst charge the cripple with.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: So sir, this is multiplication, now sir, if you know the rule of addition you are an excellent scholar: can you not add?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.l: What dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Another shilling sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: There is another shilling; now fiddle speak.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Why then attend you hills and dales, and stones so quick of hearing, this cripple is.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: What is he villain?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: An honest man, as any is in all the town.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: An honest man!

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l:
I by this silver, and as good a fellow as ever went upon
four legs, if you would multiply till midnight, I would never speak otherwise.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Fiddle, thou art a knave, and so is he:
Come let us home; Barnard, look to thy bond,
If thou do break thy day, I do protest,
By yond chaste moon.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: The chaste moon, why the moon is not chaste.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: How provest thou that?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Why sir, there's a man in the middle of her, how can she be chaste then?

sp.speaker: Berr.
sp.l: Then by my life I swear, I'll clap him up
Where he shall see neither the sun nor moon,
Till I be satisfied the utmost penny,
And so farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Gallants goodnight; if time and place were in prosperity, I were yours for an hour's society, I must after yond mulberry with my torch: adieu dear hearts, adieu. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Come Barnard, let's to the dancing, let's tickle it tonight , for tomorrow thy heels may be too heavy.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: All's one; my heart shall be as light as fire.
Come, shall we go?

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Cripple, will you along?

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: My business stays me here.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Farewell than dog of Israel, farewell. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: All's one, my heart shall be as light as fire:
'Sblood, were I indebted a hundred pound,
My fortune failed, and fled as Barnard's are,
Not worth a hundred pence as Barnard's is:
I should be now devising sentences
And caveats, for posterity to carve
Upon the inside of the counter wall:
Therefore I'll now turn provident; I'll to my shop
And fall to work.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yonder's his shop, oh now you gods above
Pity poor Phillis heart, that melts in love;
Instruct the cripple to find out my love,
Which I will shadow under the conceit
of my invention for this piece of work;
Oh teach him how to yield me love again,
A little little love, a dram of kind affection,
His many virtues are my true direction:
By your leave m. drawer.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Welcome mistress flower, what's your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My cause of coming is not unknown to you,
Here is be spoken work which must be wrought
With expedition, I pray have care of it;
The residue I refer to your direction:
Only this hankercher, a young gentlewoman,
Wished me acquaint you with her mind herein:
In one corner of the same, place wanton love,
Drawing his bow shooting an amorous dart,
Opposite against him an arrow in a heart,
In a third corner picture forth disdain,
A cruel fate unto a loving vain:
In the fourth draw a springing laurel tree,

Circled about with a ring of poesy: and thus it is:
Love wounds the heart and conquers fell disdain,
Love pities love, seeing true love in pain:
Love seeing love how faithful love did breathe,
At length impalÃ love with a laurel wreath.
Thus you have heard the gentlewoman's mind,
I pray be careful that it be well done:
And so I leave you, more I fain would say,
But shame forbids and calls me hence away. Exit.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Sweet fair, I pity, yet no relief
Harbours within the closet of my soul:
This Phillis bears me true affection,
But I detest the humour of fond love:
Yet am I hourly solicited
As now you see, and fain she would make known
The true perplexion of her wounded heart:
But modesty checking her forwardness
Bids her be still; yet she in similes
and love-comparisons, like a good scholar
By figures makes a demonstration
Of the true love enclosed in her heart.
I know it well, yet will not tell her so,
Fancy shall never marry me to woe;
Take this of me, a young man's never marred,
Till he by marriage from all joy be barred. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: You gods of love that sits above, and pity lover's pain,
Look from your thrones upon the moans, that I do now sustain.
Was ever man thus tormented with love?

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Ye little birds that sit and sing
Amid the shady valleys,
And see how Phillis sweetly walks
Within her garden alleys;
Go pretty birds about her bower,
Sing pretty birds she may not lower,
Ah me, methinks I see her frown
Ye pretty wantons warble.
Go tell her through your chirping bills,
As you by me are bidden,
To her is only known my love,
Which from the world is hidden:
Go pretty birds and tell her so,
See that your notes strain not too low,
For still methink I see her frown,
Ye pretty wantons warble.
Go tune your voices harmony,
And sing I am her lover;
Strain loud and sweet, that every note,
With sweet content may move her:
And she that hath the sweetest voice,
Tell her I will not change my choice,
Yet still methinks I see her frown,
Ye pretty wantons warble.
O fly, make haste, see, see she falls
Into a pretty slumber,
Sing round about her rosy bed
that waking she may wonder,
Say to her, 'tis her lover true,
That sendeth love to you to you:
And when you hear her kind reply,
Return with pleasant warblings.

sp.l: Avant delusion, thoughts cannot win my love;
Love, though divine, cannot divine my thoughts:
Why to the air then do I idle here
Such heedless words far off, and never the near;
Hie thee young Frank, to her that keeps thy heart,
There let sweet words they sweeter thoughts impart.
But stay; here comes my melancholy brothers both,
I'll step aside, and hear their conference. Exit aside.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: What? is my brother Ferdinand so near?
He is my elder, I must needs give place;
Anthony, stand by, and list what he doth say,
Haste calls me hence, yet I will brook delay.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Shall I exclaim 'gainst fortune and mishap.
Or rail on nature who first framed me?
Is it hard chance that keeps me from my love?
Or is this heap of loathed deformity,
The cause that breeds a blemish in her eye?
I know not what to think, or what to say,
Only one comfort yet I have in store,
Which I will practise though I never try more.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: O, for to hear that comfort I do long,
I'll turn it to a strain to right my wrong.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I have a brother rival in my love;
I have a brother hates me for my love;
I have a brother vows to win my love;
That brother too, he hath incensed my love,
To gain the beauty of my dearest love;
What hope remains then to enjoy my love?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I am that brother rival in his love,
I am that brother hates him for his love:
Not his but mine, and I will have that love,
Or never live to see him kiss my love;
What thou erst said, I am that man alone,
That will depose you brother from love's throne;
I am that man, though you my elder be,
That will aspire beyond you one degree.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I have no means of private conference,
So narrowly pursues my hinderer,
No sooner am I entered the sweet court
Of lovely rest, my love's rich mansion,
But rival love to my affection
Follows me, as a soon enforced straw,
The drawing virtue of a sable jet:
This therefore's my determination,
Within the close womb of a sealed paper,
Will I right down in bloody characters,
The burning zeal of my affection:
And by some trusty messenger or other,
Convey the same into my love's own hand;
So shall I know her resolution,
And how she fancies my affection.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Yet subtle fox, I may perchance to cross you:
Brother, well met; whither away so fast?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: About affairs that do require some haste.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: 'Tis well done brother, you seek still for gain.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: But you would reap the harvest of my pain:
Farewell good brother, I must needs be gone,
I have serious business now to think upon:
Yet for I fear my brother Anthony,
I'll step aside and stand a while unseen,
I may perchance descry which way he goes;
Thus policy must work twixt friends and foes. Aside.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: So, he is gone, I scarcely trust him neither;
For 'tis his custom, like a sneaking fool,
To fetch a compass of a mile about,
And creep where he would be; well, let him pass,
I heard him say, that since by word of mouth
He could not purchase his sweet mistress favour,
He would endeavour what his wit might do
By writing, and by tokens; oh 'tis good
Writing with ink; oh no, but with his blood.
Well, so much for that, now I know his mind
I do intend not to be far behind:
He'll send a letter, I will write another,
Do what you can, I'll be before you brother;
I'll intercept his letter by the way,
And as time serves, the same I will bewray:
Mine being made, a porter I'll procure,
That shall convey that heart-enticing lure;
About it then, my letter shall be writ,
Though not with blood, yet with a reaching wit. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: And shall it so, good brother Anthony?
Were you so near when we in secret talked?
Wilt never be otherwise? will you dog me still?
Welcome sweet Frank; such news I have to tell,
As cannot choose but like thee passing well:
Thou knowest my love to Phillis?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Brother, say on.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Thou likewise art acquainted with my rival,
And I do build upon your secrecy.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: 'Sblood, and I thought you did not, I'd retire:
Brother you know, I love you as my life.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I dare profess as much, and thereupon
Make bold to crave thy furtherance, in a thing
Concerns me much.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Out with it brother;
If I shrink back, repose trust in some other.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Then thus it is; my brother all in haste
Is gone, to write a letter to my love,
And thinks thereby to cross me in my suit,
Sending it by a porter to her hand;
If ever therefore thou wilt aid thy brother,
Help me in this, who seeks help from no other.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: By the red lip of that dainty saint, I'll aid thee all I may.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: It is enough; then brother I'll provide
A porter's habit, alike in every point,
Will you but so much humble your estate,
To put yourself in that so base attire,
And like so mean a person wait his coming,
about his door which will not be o'er long,
Thou shalt for ever bind me to thy love.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Brother, 'tis a base task, by this light,
But to procure a further force of love,
I'll do't, i'faith I will sweet Ferdinand,
About it then, provide thee some disguise,
But see you stay not long in any wise,
Here shall you find me, go, dispatch.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: For this I'll love thee everlastingly.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Mean time I'll cross your love and if I can.
Here's no villainy twixt us three brothers:
My brother Ferdinand he would have the wench,
And Anthony he hopes to have her too:
Then what may I? faith hope well, as they do.
Neither of them know that I love the maid;
Yet by this hand I am half mad for love.
I know not well what love is, but 'tis sure,
I'll die if I have her not, therefore
Good brothers mine beguile you one another,
Till you be both gulled by your younger brother.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Here is a porter's habit, on with it brother.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Your hand then brother for to put it on,
So now 'tis well, come brother, what's my task?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: This first, that thou make haste to Anthony's,
Ask for a burden and thou shall be sure
To have his letter to my dear love Phillis,
Deliver it not, but keep it to thyself,
Till thou hast given this paper to her hands,
Whose lines do intimate thy chaste desires.
This is the sum of all, good Frank, make haste,
Love burns in me, and I in love do waste. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Waste still, but let me in my love increase,
Now would not all the world take me for a porter?
How strangely am I metamorphosed?
And yet I need not be ashamed neither,
Jove when his love-scapes when he attempted ever
Transformed himself, yet ever sped in love,
why may not I then in this strange disguise?
This habit may prove mighty in love's power,
As beast, or bird, bull, or swan, or golden shower.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Within the centre of this paper square,
Have I wrote down in bloody characters,
A pretty poesy of a wounded heart,
Such is love's force once burst into a flame,
Do what we can we cannot quench the same,
Unless the tears of pity move compassion,
And so quench out the fire of affection,
Whose burning force heats me in every vain,
That I to love for safety must complain:
This is my orator whose dulcet tongue
Must plead my love to beauteous Phillis.
Now for a trusty messenger to be
Employed herein betwixt my love and me,
And in good time I see a porter nigh,
Come hither fellow, dwellest thou here about?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Sir, my abiding is not far from hence,
And trusty John men call me by my name.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Canst thou be trusty then, and secret too,
Being employed in weighty business?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Sir, I was never yet disproved in either.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Then mark me well, in Cornhill by th'exchange,
Dwells an old merchant, flower they call his name,
He hath one only daughter, to whose hands,
If thou conveniently canst give this letter,
I'll pay thee well, make thee the happiest porter
That ever undertook such business.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Sir, give me your letter, if I do it not,
Then let your promised favour be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Anthony Golding is my name, my friend,
About it then, thy message being done,
Make haste to me again, till when, I leave thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: And so fare thee well loving brother,
It had been better you had sent some other,
Let me consider what is best be done,
shall I deliver his letter? No:
Shall I convey it to my rival brother? Nor so:
Shall I tear the same? No not for a million:
What shall I then do? marry like a kind brother,
Open the book, see what is written there,
If naught but love, in love have thou a share.
Brother, by your leave I hope you'll not deny,
But that I love you: God bless my eyesight,
A sonnet 'tis in verse, now on my life
He hath perused all the impressions
Of sonnets since the fall of Lucifer,
And made some scurvy quaint collection
Of fustian phrases, and uplandish words.

body.head: A letter.
body.l: Fair glory of virtue, thy enamorate
Whose passion love do thou exonerate,
And he shall live by thy protection:
Nor from thy love shall he once derogate,
For any soul under this horizon,
Yield thou to love, and I will fail in neither,
So love and truth shall always live together.

sp.l: Before God, excellent good poetry,
'Sblood what means he by this line?
For any soul under this horizon?
No matter for his meaning, mean what he will,
I mean his meaning shall not be delivered,
But for my other trust my other letter,
That shall come short too of fair Phillis hands,
There is a cripple dwelling here at hand,
That's very well acquainted with the maid,
And for I once did rescue them from thieves,
Swore, if he lived, he would requite that kindness,
To him I will for council, he shall be
My tutor by his wit and policy. Exit.

div.stage: Enter boy in a shop cutting of square parchments, to him enter Phillis.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why how now sirrah, can you find naught to do,
But waste the parchment in this idle sort?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: I do but what my mistress gave in charge.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Your mistress! in good time: then sir it seems
Your duty cannot stoop but to her lewre:
Sir, I will make you know, that in her absence
You shall account to my demand, your mistress
And your mistress will is thus, and thus you'll do:
But answer to the motion I have made,
Or you shall feel you have another mistress now:
Speak, why when I say?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: Indeed I know your glory.
Your pride's at full in this authority:
But, were it not for modest bashfulness,
And that I dread a base contentious name,
I would not be a byword to th'exchange,
For every one to say (My self going by)
Yond goes a vassal to authority.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You would not sir: had I the yard in hand,
I'd measure your pate for this delusion,
And by my maiden chastity I swear,
UnlessReach for the yard, and the boy stay her hand.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: What unless! I know your wilfulness,
These words are but to show the world your humour.
I often use to square these parchment pieces
Without occasion: I am sure you are not witting
The lawns you lately bought of master brooks
Are new come home, brought by the merchant's servant:
I know you are short membered, but not so short
Of your remembrance, that this is news to you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You're best to brave me in a taunting humour.
Will't please you open the door? where's Ursula?
O here's good stuff, my back's no sooner turned
But she must needs be gadding, and where I pray?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: She's gone to m. Pawmer's on th'other side.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: On great occasions, sir, I doubt it not.

div.stage: Sit and work in the shop.
Enter m. Richard Gardiner booted, and m. William Bennet, two gentlemen, at one end of the stage.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Kind Dick, thou wilt not be unmindful of my duty
To that same worthy arts-master, Lyonell Barnes.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Thy love, sweet will, hath chained it to my memory.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Then with this kind embrace I take my leave,
Wishing thou wert as safe arrived at Cambridge,
As thou art at this present near the exchange.

sp.speaker: Gard
sp.l: And well remembered, kind will Bennet,
Others affairs made me oblivious
Of mine own; I pray thee go to the exchange,
I have certain bands, and other linen to buy,
Prithee accompany me.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Sure, this is a beauteous gallant walk.
Were my continual residence in London,
I should make much use of such a pleasure:
Methinks the glorious virgins of this square
Gives life to dead strucke youth; o heavens!

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Why how now Dick?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: By my sweet hopes of an hereafter bliss,
I never saw a fairer face than this:
Oh for acquaintance with so rich a beauty.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Take thy occasion, never hadst thou better.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Have at her then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What lack you gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Faith nothing, had I thee.
For in thine eye all my desires I see.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My shop you mean sir, there you may have choice
Of lawns, or cambrics, ruffs well wrought, shirts,
Fine falling bands of the Italian cutwork,
Ruffs for your hands, waistcoats wrought with silk,
Nightcaps of gold, or such like wearing linen,
Fit for the chapman of whate'er degree.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Faith virgin in my days, I have worn and outworn much,
Yea, many of these golden necessaries;
But such a gallant beauty, or such a form
I never saw, nor never wore the like:
Faith be not then unkind, but let me wear
This shape of thine, although I buy it dear.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What hath the tailor played his part so well,
That with my gown you are so far in love?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Mistake not sweet your garment is the cover,
That veils the shape and pleasures of a lover.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That argues then, you do not see my shape,
How comes it then you are in love with it?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: A garment made by cunning artsmen's skill,
Hides all defects that nature's swerving hand
Hath done amiss, and makes the shape seem pure;
If then it grace such lame deformity,
It adds a greater grace to purity.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O short lived praise! even now I was as fair
As any thing; now fouler nothing.
Dissembling men, what maid will credit them?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: How misconstruction leads your thoughts awry.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I prithee Dick adone; think on thy journey.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You counsel well sir, I think the gentleman
Comes but to whet his wit, and 'tis but need;
'Tis blunt enough, he may ride far upon't.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Marry gip minx.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A fine word in a gentleman's mouth;
'Twere good your back were towards me,
There can I read better content, then in the face of lust.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Now you display your virtues, as they are.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What am I, you, cipher, parenthesis of words,
Stall-troubler, prater, what sit I here for naught?
Bestow your lustful courtships on your minions,
This place holds none; you and your companion
Get you down the stairs, or I protest
I'll make this squared walk too botte for you.
Had you been as you seemed in outward show,
Honest gentlemen, such terms of vild abuse
had not been proffered to virginity;
But swains will quickly show their base descent.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: This is no place for brawls, but if it were,
Your impositions are more than I would bear.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Come, she's a woman, I prithee leave her.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay sure a maid, unless her thoughts deceive her.
God speed you well: sirrah boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Anon.
Goded to the starchers for the suit of ruffs,
For m. Bowdler's bands, and m. Golding's shirts,
Let's have a care to please our proved friends:
As for our strangers, if they use us well,
For love and money, love and ware we'll sell.Exeunt

div.stage: Enter Frank. The cripple at work.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Now fortune be my guide, this is the shop;
And in good time the cripple is at work:
God speed you sir.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Welcome honest friend; what's thy will with me?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I would entreat you read a letter for me.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: With all my heart:
I know the maid to whom it is directed.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I know you do Cripple, better than you think.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: I pray you, what gentleman writ the same?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Sir, a gentleman of good learning, and my friend;
To say the truth, was written for myself,
Being somewhat overtaken with fond love,
As many men be sir.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Why art thou persuaded, or haste thou any hope,
So beautiful a virgin as she is,
Of such fair parentage; so virtuous,
So gentle, kind, and wise as Phillis is,
That she will take remorse of such base stuff,
I think not so: but let me see, what's thy name?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Trusty John men call me sir.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: How comes it then your blinded secretary,
Hath writ another name unto the letter?
Yours devoted Anthony Golding.
But sure this letter is no right of thine,
Either thou foundst the same by happy chance,
Or being employed as a messenger,
Play'dst leger dumaine with him that sent the same:
Wherefore the maid (Well known unto myself)
I will reserve the letter to her use,
That she, if by the name herein set down,
She know the gentleman that doth wish her well,
She may be grateful for his courtesy.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Nay then I see I must disclose myself:
Sir, might I build upon your secrecy,
I would disclose a secret of import.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Assure thyself I will not injure thee.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Then Cripple know, I am not what I seem,
But took this habit to deceive my friend:
My friend indeed, but yet my cruel foe;
Foe to my good, my friend in outward show:
I am no porter, as I seem to be,
But younger brother to that Anthony;
And to be brief, I am in love with Phillis,
Which my two elder brothers do affect:
The one of them seeks to defeat the other:
Now if that I, being their younger brother
Could gull them both, by getting of the wench,
I would requite it with love's recompense.
Cripple, thou once didst promise me thy love,
When I did rescue thee on Mile-end green,
Now is the time, now let me have thy aid,
To gull my brothers of that beauteous maid.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Sir, what I promised I will now perform;
My love is yours, my life to do you good,
Which to approve, follow me but in all,
We'll gull your brothers in the wench, and all.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Sayest thou me so friend, for that very word
My life is thine, command my hand and sword.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Then let me see this letter; it should see me
You undertook to carry from your brother
To the maid.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: I did, and from my brother Ferdinand,
This other letter to the same effect.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Well, list to me, and follow my advice,
You shall deliver neither of them both;
But frame two letters of your own invention,
Letters of flat denial to their suits,
Give them to both your brothers as from Phillis,
And let each line in either letter tend
To the dispraise of both their features;
And the conclusion I would have set down,
A flat resolve bound with some zealous oath,
Never to yield to either of their suits:
And if this sort not well to your content,
Condemn the cripple.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: But this will ask much time,
And they by this time look for my return.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Why then myself will fit you presently,
I have the copies in my custody,
Of sundry letters to the same effect.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Of thy own writing?

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: My own I assure you, sir.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Faith thou hast robbed some sonnet book or other,
And now wouldst make me think they are thine own.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Why, thinkst thou that I cannot write a letter,
Ditty, or sonnet with judicial phrase,
As pretty, pleasing, and pathetical,
As the best ovid-imitating dance
In all the town.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: I think thou canst not.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Yea, I'll swear I cannot,
Yet sirrah, I could coney-catch the world,
Make myself famous for a sudden wit,
And be admired for my dexterity,
Were I disposed.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: I pray thee how.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Why thus there lived a poet in this town,
(If we may term our modern writers poets)
Sharp-witted, bitter-tongued, his pen of steel,
his ink was tempered with the biting juice,
And extracts of the bitter'st weeds that grew,
He never wrote but when the elements
Of fire and water tilted in his brain:
This fellow ready to give up his ghost
To Lucia's bosom, did bequeathe to me
His library, which was just nothing,
But rolls, and scrolls, and bundles of cast wit,
Such as durst never visit Paul's churchyard:
Amongst them all, I happened on a choir
Or two of paper filled with songs and ditties,
And here and there a hungry epigram,
These I reserve to my own proper use,
And pater-noster-like have conned them all.
I could now when I am in company,
At ale house, tavern, or an ordinary,
Upon a theme make an extemporal ditty,
(Or one at least should seem extemporal)
Out of th'abundance of this legacy,
That all would judge it, and report it too,
To be the infant of a sudden wit,
And then were I an admirable fellow.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: This were a piece of cunning.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: I could do more, for I could make enquiry
Where the best witted gallants use to dine,
Follow them to the tavern, and there sit
In the next room with a calf's head and brimstone,
And over hear their talk, observe their humours,
Collect their jests, put them into a play,
And tire them too with payment to behold
What I have filched from them. This I could do:
But oh for shame that men should so arraign
Their own fee simple wits, for verbal theft!
Yet men there be that have done this and that,
And more by much more than the most of them.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: But to our purpose Cripple to these letters.

sp.speaker: Cripple
sp.l: I have them ready for you, here they be,
Give these to your two brothers, say that Phillis
delivered them with frowns, and though her name
Be not subscribed (Which may not well be done)
It may perhaps give them occasion
To think she scorned them so much grace and favour.
This done, return to me, and let me know
Th'occurrants of this practice as they grow,
And so farewell, I can no longer stand
To talk with you, I have some work in hand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Farewell mad Cripple, now Frank Golding sly,
To put in practise this new policy:
But soft, here comes the maid, I will assay
To plead my own love by a stranger way,
By your leave sir.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Porter, I am not for you, you see I am perambulating before a female.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: I would crave but a word with you.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Speak in time then porter, for otherwise I do not love to answer you, and be as brief as you can, good porter.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I pray you sir, what gentlewoman is this?

sp.speaker: Fiddle.
sp.p: Certes porter, I serve a gentleman, that gentleman is father to this gentlewoman, this gentlewoman is a maid, this maid is fair, and this fair maid belongeth to the exchange, and the exchange hath not the like fair maid now porter, put all this together, and tell me what it spells.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: I promise you sir, you have posed me.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Then you are an ass porter, 'tis the fair maid of the exchange.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Her name I pray you sir.

sp.speaker: Fiddle.
sp.p: Her name porter requires much poeticality in the subscription, and no less judgement in the understanding; her name is Phillis, not Phillis that same dainty lass that was beloved of Amintas, nor Phillis she that doted on that comely youth Demophoon, but this is Phillis, that most strange Phillis, the flower of the exchange.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What, would that porter any thing with me?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Yes mistress, since by chance I meet you here,
I'll tell you, though it not concerns myself,
What I this morning saw; there is a gentleman
One master Golding the youngest of three brothers,
They call him Frank; oh this man lies very sick,
I being at his house perchance inquired
What his disease was of a servant there,
Who said, the doctors cannot tell themselves,
But in his fits he ever calls on love,
And prays to love for pity, and then names you,
And then names love again, and then calls Phillis,
And sometime starts, and would forsake his bed,
And being asked whither, he says he would go to Phillis,
My business called me hence, but I heard say
His friends do mean to entreat you to take the pains
To visit him, because they do suppose,
The sick man loves you, and thence his sickness grows.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Porter, is this true?
Or art thou hired to this, I prithee tell me.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Mistress, not hired, my name is trusty John.
If I delude you, never trust me more.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I thank thee porter, and thank love withal,
That thus hath wrought the tyrant Golding's fall,
He once scorned love, jested at wounded hearts,
Challenged almighty beauty, railed at passion,
And is he now caught by the eyes and heart?
Now by Diana's milk white veil I swear,
The goddess of my maiden chaste desires.
I am as glad of it as glad may be,
And I will see him, if but to laugh at him,
And torture him with jests; fiddle, along,
When we return, if they do send for me,
I'll arm myself with flouts and cruelty.

sp.speaker: Fiddle
sp.l: Porter, we commit you, if you be a crafty knave, and lay in the wind for a vantage, you have your answer: mark her last words, I'll arm myself with flouts and cruelty. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I'll arm myself with flouts and cruelty.
Will you so Phillis, what a state am I in?
Why I of all am furthest from her love:
'Sblood, if I now should take conceit at this,
Fall sick with love indeed, were not my state
Most lamentable? I by this hand were it:
Well heart, if thou wilt yield, look to thyself,
Thou wilt be tortured, well what remedy.
Here comes my brother Anthony, I am for him.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Porter, what news? spoke you with Phillis?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I too late, to my grief,
Spoke with her, sir, i'faith I think I have;
Here's a letter for you, and by that
You shall be judge if I did speak with her;
Now Cripple, shall we prove your learned wit?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Zounds am I mad, or is she mad that writ this?
I'll read it o'er again:

body.head: A letter.
body.p: Sir, I did never like you, I do not now think well of you, and I will never love you: I choose my husband with my eyes, and I have seen some especial fault in you; as the colour of your hair, the elevating of your head, to an affected proportion, as if you fainted for want of air, and stood in that manner to suck it into your nose, your neck is too long: and to be short, I like no part in or about you: and the short and the long boy, is, that I will never love you, and I will never marry but one I love.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Blank, I am struck blank, and blind, and mad withal,
Here is a flat denial to my suit,
A resolution never to be won:
What shall I do? assist me God of love,
Instruct me in thy school-tricks; be my guide
Out of this labyrinth of love and fear,
Unto the palace of fair Phillis favour:
I have it; I will intimate her mother
In my behalf, with letters and with gifts,
To her I'll write to be my advocate:
Porter farewell, there's for thy pains,
Thy profit by this toil passeth my gains. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: You have your answer, and a kind one too;
Cripple I'll make thee crutches of pure silver
For this device, thou hast a golden wit;
Now if my brother Ferdinand were here
To read his absolution, here he comes.
Brother.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Frank.
What hast thou given the letter to her hand,
And stayed my brother Anthony's withal?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: I have done both, and more than that, behold
Here is an answer to your letter brother.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Frank, I will love thee, whiles I live for this.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Scarce, when you read what there contained is.

body.head: A letter.
body.p: Gallant, that write for love, if you had come yourself yond might perchance have sped; I do not counsel you neither, to come yourself, unless you leave your head at home, or wear a vizard, or come backwards, for I never look you in the face but I am sick: and so praying God to continue my health, by keeping you from me, I leave you.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: O unkind answer to a lover's letter;
Let me survey the end once more:For I never look you in the face but I am sick: and so praying God to continue me in health, by keeping you from me.
Is she so far from yielding? is this fort
Of her chaste love yet so impregnable?
What shall I do? this is the furthest way,
A labour of impossibilities:
This way to win her? I will once again,
Challenge the promise that her father made me;
To him I'll write, and he I know will plead
My love to Phillis, and so win the maid. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Farewell poor tortured heart; was ever known
Two loving brothers in such misery?
Let me consider of my own estate:
What profit do I reap by this delusion?
Why none; I am as far from Phillis heart
As when she first did wound me with her eyes:
Cripple, to thee I come, 'tis thou must be
My counsellor in this extremity. Exit.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: Sirrah Bowdler, what makes thee in this merry vain?

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.p: O lord sir, it is your most elevated humour to be merry, to be concise, set up the collar, and look thus with a double chin, like Diogenes peering over his tub, is too cynical, the sign of melancholy, and indeed, the mere effect of a salt rheum.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: Who would think this gentleman yesterday's distemperature should breed such motions? I think it be restorative to activity, I never saw a gentleman caper so excellent, as he did last night.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Mean you me sir?

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Your own self, by this hand.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: You gull me not.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: How, gull you!
Methinks a man so well reputed of,
So well commended for your qualities
In schools of nimble activeness,
And places where divinest choristers
Warble enchanting harmony, to such
As think there is no heaven on earth but theirs:
And knowing yourself to be the genius
Of the spectators, and the audience hearts,
You wrong your worthy self intolerably,
To think our words savour of flattery.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Sirrah dog, how didst thou like my last caper, and turn a the toe?

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Before God passing well.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: I know his worship made it, 'tis so excellent,

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: It was my yesterday's exercise.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: After the working of your purgation, was it not?

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: What purgation, you filthy cur?

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: After the purging of your brain sir.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Be still dog, bark not, though by misfortune
I was last night somewhat distempered:
I will not be upbraided; was no more
But to refine my wit; but tell me truly,
How dost thou like my caper?

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Far better than I can commend it.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Now as I am a gentleman
My tutor was not witting of the same;
And in my opinion 'twill do excellent:
Oh this air! here's a most eloquious air for the memory,
I could spend the third part of my arms in silver,
To be encountered by some good wit or other.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: What say you to your sweet heart, mall Berry?

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.p: Peace Cripple, silence, name her not, I could not endure the career of her wit, for a million, she is the only she Mercury under the heavens; her wit is all spirit; that spirit fire, that fire flies from her tongue, able to burn the radix of the best invention; in this element she is the abstract and brief of all the eloquence since the incarnation of Tully's I tell thee Cripple, I had rather encounter Hercules with blows, than mall Berry with words: and yet by this light I am horribly in love with her.
