sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: See where she comes, oh excellent!

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Now have I no more blood than a bulrush.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: How now; what ail you sir?

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: What's the matter man?

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: See, see, that glorious angel doth approach,
What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: She is a saint indeed; zounds to her, court her, win her, wear her, wed her, and bed her too.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: I would it were come to that, I win her! by heaven, I am not furnished of a courting phrase, to throw at a dog.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l:
Why no, but at a woman you have; oh sir, seem not so doltish now, can you make no fustian, ask her if she'll
take a pipe of tobacco.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: It will offend her judgement, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: But hear you sir? reading so much as you have done,
Do you not remember one pretty phrase,
To scale the walls of a fair wench's love?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: I never read any thing but Venus and Adonis.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Why that's the very quintessence of love,
If you remember but a verse or two,
I'll pawn my head, goods, lands and all 'twill do.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Why then have at her.
Fondling I say, since I have hemmed thee here,
Within the circle of this ivory pale,
I'll be a park.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Hands off fond sir.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: And thou shalt be my dear;
Feed thou on me, and I will feed on thee,
And love shall feed us both.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Feed you on woodcocks, I can fast awhile.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Vouchsafe thou wonder to alight thy steed.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Take heed, she's not on horseback.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Why then she is alighted,
Come sit thee down where never serpent hisses,
And being set, I'll smother thee with kisses.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why is your breath so hot? now God forbid
I should buy kisses to be smothered.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Mean you me? you gull me not?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: No, no, poor Bowdler, thou dost gull thyself:
Thus must I do to shadow the hid fire,
That in my heart doth burn with hot desire:
Oh I do love him well whate'er I say,
Year will I not myself self love bewray,
If he be wise he'll sue with good take heed:
Bowdler, do so, and thou art sure to speed:
I will fly hence to make his love the stronger,
Though my affection must lie hid the longer.
What master Bowdler, not a word to say?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: No by my troth, if you stay here all day.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why then I'll bear the bucklers hence away. Exit.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: What master Bowdler, have you let her pass unconquered?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Why what could I do more? I looked upon her with judgement, the strings of my tongue were well in tune, my embraces were in good measure, my palm of a good constitution, only the phrase was not moving; as for example, Venus herself with all her skill could not win Adonis, with the same words: oh heavens! was I so fond then to think that I could conquer Mall Berry? O the natural fluence of my own wit had been far better!
sp.l: God-den good fellow.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: God give you the time of the day, pardon me gallants, I was so near the middle that I knew not which hand to take.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: A very good conceit.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And yet because I will be sure to give you a true salutation, Cripple, quomodo vales? Good morrow Cripple, good-den good master Barnard, master Bowdler, bonos noches, as they say, good night; and thus you have heard my manner of salutation.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: You are very eloquent, sir; but fiddle, what's the best news abroad?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: The best news I know not sir, but the newest news is most excellent i'faith.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.p: Prithee let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Why this it is, the sergeants are watching to arrest you at master Berry's suit.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.p: Wounds, where?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Nay, I know not where; alas sir, there is no such matter, I did but say so much, to make you warm the handle of your rapier: but m. Bawdler, I have good news for you.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Let me hear it, my sweet russetting.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: How, russeting?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: I my little apple John.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: You are a

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: A what?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: You are a, oh that I could speak for indignation!

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Nay, what am I?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Yond are a pippinmonger to call me Russeting or apple John.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Sirrah Russeting, I'll pare your head off.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: You pippinmonger, I'll cut off your legs, and make you travel so near the mother earth, that every boy shall be high enough to steal apples out of thy basket, call me russetting?

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: Nay, be friends, be friends.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: As I am a gentleman cripple, I meant him no harm, but the name of Russeting to master fiddle, that many times travels under the arm in velvet, but for the most part in leather trussed with calf-skin points, 'tis most tolerable, and not to be endured, flesh and blood cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: Come, come, all shall be well.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Fiddle, give me thy hand, a plague on thee, thou knowest I love thee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Say you so? why then anger avoid the room, melancholy march away, choler to the next chamber, and here's my hand I am yours to command from this time forth, your very mortal friend, and loving enemy, master fiddle.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Now tell us, what is the news you had for me?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: O, the sweet news, faith sir, this it is, that I was sent to the cripple from my young mistress. Master Cripple you know I have spent some time in idle words, therefore be you compendious, and tell me if my mistress handkercher be done or no.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Fiddle 'tis done, and peace it is, commend me to thy mistress.

sp.speaker: Fidd.
sp.p: After the most humble manner I will; and so gentlemen I commit you all: you Cripple to your shop; you sir, to a turnup and dish of capers; and lastly, you m. Barnard, to the tuition of the counter-keeper: there's an item for you, and so farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: M. Bowdler, how do you like his humour?

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.p: By this light, I had not thought the clod had had so nimble a spirit: but Cripple farewell, I'll to Mall Berry, come Barnard along with me.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: Farewell sweet signiors both, farewell, farewell. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter m. Flower at one door reading a letter from Ferdinand, at the other mistress Flower, with a letter from Anthony.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.p: The conceit is good, Ferdinand entreats a marriage with my daughter; good, very good: for he is a gentleman of good carriage, a wise man, a rich man, a careful man, and therefore worthy of my daughter's love: it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.p: Marry and shall, kind gentleman, my furtherance sayest thou? Yes Anthony, assure thyself, for by the motherly care that I bear to my daughter, it hath been a desire that long hath lodged within my careful breast, to match her with thy well-deserving self; and to this end have I sent for my daughter, and charged my servants, that presently upon her repair hither from her mistresses, that she enter this private walk, where, and with whom, I will so work, that doubt it not, dear son, but she shall be thine.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.p: And I will make her jointure of a hundred pounds by year: it is a very good conceit, and why? because the worthy portion betters my conceit, which being good in conceiving well of the gentleman's good parts, the proffered jointure adds to my conceit, and betters it, very good.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.p: A thousand crowns for you to make the match, pretty heart, how love can work! by god's blessed mother, I vow she shall be thine, if I have any interest in my daughter;Flower smiles reading the letter, they snatch the letter from each other.but stay, whom have I espied? my husband likewise reading of a letter, and in so good an humour, I'll lay my life, good gentleman he hath also wrought with him for his good will; and for I long to know the truth thereof, my sudden purpose shall experience it. What's here husband? She reads privately, and frowns.a letter from master Ferdinand, to entreat a marriage with your daughter.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.p: And here the like to you from Anthony to that effect, this is no good conceit, if she be mine, she shall be Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: If she respect her mother's favour,
'Tis Anthony shall be her love.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: How wife?

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Even so husband.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: You will not cross my purpose, will you?

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: In this you shall not bridle me I swear.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Is she not my daughter?

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: You teach me husband, what your wife should say,
I think her life is dearest unto me,
Though you forget the long extremity
And pain which I endured, when forth this womb
With much ado she did enjoy the life she now doth breathe,
And shall I now suffer her destruction?

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Yea but conceit me wife.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: A fig for your conceits, in this I know there can be none that:
Say he be his father's eldest son, and a merchant of good wealth, yet my dear Anthony's as rich as he:
What though his portion was but small at first,
His industry hath now increased his talon;
And he that knoweth the getting of a penny,
Will fear to spend, she shall have him, if any.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: By the Mary God wife, you vex me.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis your own impatience, you may choose.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: I will not wed my daughter to that Anthony.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: By this.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Hold wife, hold, I advise thee swear not,
For by him that made me, first I vow,
She shall not touch the bed of Anthony.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: And may I never live (So God me help)
If ever she be wed to Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: The devil's in this woman, how she thwarts me still!

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Fret on, good husband, I will have my will.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: But conceit me wife, suppose we should consent our daughter should wed either of them both, and she dislike the match, were that a good conceit?

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: All's one for that, I know my daughter's mind if I but say the word.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: I would be loath to wed her against her will,
Content thee wife, we'll hear her resolution,
And as I find her, to her own content
to either of them she shall have my consent.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Why now old flower speaketh like himself.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Agreed, and faith wife 'tis a good conceit,
And see where my daughter comes: welcome girl,
How doth your mistress Phillis? God bless thee Phillis, rise.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: God have the glory, in perfect health she is.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis good, I am glad she doth so well;
But list my daughter, I have golden news
To impart unto thee:
A golden, Golding, wench, must be thy husband,
Is't not a good conceit?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Father, I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Then, my girl, thy conceit is very shallow,
Master Ferdinand Golding is in love with thee.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: No daughter, 'tis thine Anthony.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Ferdinand is rich, for he hath store of gold.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Anthony is rich, yet is not so old.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Ferdinand is virtuous, full of modesty.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Anthony's more gracious, if more may be.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Ferdinand is wise (Being wise) who would not love him.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Anthony more wise, than girl desire to prove him.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: In Ferdinand is all the beauty that may be.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: He is deceived, 'tis in thine Anthony.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Dear parents, you confound me with your words,
I pray what mean these hot persuasions?

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Thy good my daughter.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: If but ruled by me.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: But for thy illfare.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: If she tend to thee.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: The truth is this, that each of us hath ta'en
A solemn vow, that thou my loving daughter
Shalt wed with one of those two gentlemen:
But yet refer the choice unto thyself,
One thou shalt love, love Ferdinand, if me.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: If love thy mother, love thine Anthony.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: In these extremes what shall become of me?
I pray you give me respite to consider
How to digest these impositions,
You have imposed a business of such weight,
Pray God your daughter may discharge herself.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Think on't, my girl, we will withdraw awhile.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: A little respite fits my resolution,They walk.
Those gentles sue too late, there is another,
Of better worth, though not of half their wealth,
What though deformed, his virtue mends that miss;
What though not rich, his wit doth better gold,
And my estate shall add unto his wants,
I am resolved (Good father, and dear mother,)
Phillis doth choose a cripple, and none other;
But yet I must dissemble.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: How now my soul's best hope! tell me, my girl,
Shall Ferdinand be he?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I pray a word in private.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Marry with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: In all the duty that a child can show,
The love that to a father it doth owe;
I yield myself to be at your command,
And vow to wed no man but Ferdinand.
But if you please, at your departure hence,
You may enforce dislike to cloud your brow,
To avoid my mother's anger and suspicion.

sp.speaker: M Flo.
sp.l: Before God a very good conceit,
Hence baggage, out of my sight,
Come not within my doors, thou hadst been better,
Run millions of miles bare footed, then
Thus by your coy disdain to have deluded me.
O mine own flesh and blood, the mirror of wit!
Now will I hence, and with all the speed I may
Send for my son, I'll have it done this day. Exit old Flow.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flow.
sp.l: What, is he gone? and in so hot a chafe?
Well let him go, I need not question why,
For well I wot his suit is cold, 'tmust die.
Daughter, I gather by thy pleasant smiles,
Thy mother hath more interest in thy love,
than discontented flower thy aged father.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Mother, you have, for when I well consider
A mother's care unto her dear bought child,
How tenderly you nursed and brought me up,
I could not be so much unnatural
As to refuse the love you proffer me,
Especially being for my chiefest good;
Therefore when married I intend to be,
My loyal husband shall be Anthony.

sp.speaker: Mistress Fl.
sp.l: Live ever then my dear dear daughter Phillis,
Let me embrace thee in a mother's arms;
Thus, thus and thus I'll ever hug my daughter,
Him hence thou sendest with frowns, me hence with laughter,
Come Phillis, let us in.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Forsooth I'll follow you.
Am not I a good child think you,
To play with both hands thus against my parents?
Well, 'tis but a trick of youth: say what they will,
I'll love the cripple, and will hate them still. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Cripple in his shop, and to him enters Frank.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Mirror of kindness, extremities best friend,
While I breathe, sweet blood, I am thine,
Entreat me, nay command thy Frances heart,
That wilt not suffer my ensuing smart.

sp.speaker: Cripp.
sp.l: Sweet signior, my advice in the reservation of those letters,
Which I will have you hide from eye of day,
Never to feel the warmth of Phoebus beams,
Till myself's care, most careful of your weal,
Summon those lines unto the bar of joy.

sp.speaker: Francke
sp.l: I will not err, dear friend, in this command.

sp.speaker: Cripple
sp.l: So much for that, now listen further Frank,
Not yet two hours expiration,
Have taken final end, since beauty's pride,
And nature's better part of workmanship,
beauteous Phillis was with me consorted;
Where she amongst other pleasing conference,
Burst into terms of sweet affection,
And said, ere long she would converse with me
In private at my shop, whose wounded soul
Struck with love's golden arrow lives in dread,
Till she do hear the sentence of my love,
Or be condemned by judgement of fell hate.
Now since that gracious opportunity
Thus smiles on me, I will resign the same
To you my friend, knowing my unworthy self
Too foul for such a beauty, and too base
To match in brightness with that sacred comet.
That shines like Phoebus in London's element;
From whence inferior stars derive their light:
Wherefore I will immediately you take
My crooked habit, and in that disguise
Court her, yea win her, for she will be won,
This will I do, to pleasure you my friend.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: For which my love to thee shall never end.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: About it then, assume this shape of mine,
Take what I have. for all I have is thine?
Supply my place, to gain thy hearts desire,
So may you quench too hearts that burn like fire:
She's kind to me, be she as kind to you,
What admiration will there then ensue?
Frank, I will leave thee, now be thou fortunate,
That we with joy your loves may consummate,
Farewell, farewell, when I return again,
I hope to find three in a pleasing vain. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Farewell dear friend; was ever known a finer policy?
Now brothers, have amongst you for a third part,
Nay, for the whole, or by my soul, I'll lose all,
What though my father did bequeath his lands
To you my elder brothers, the movables I sue for
Were none of his: and you shall run through fire,
Before you touch one part of my desire:
Am I not like myself in this disguise,
crooked in shape, and crooked in my thoughts
Then am I a cripple right, come wench, away,
Thy absence breeds a terror to my stay.
Yonder she comes, now frame thy hands to draw,
A worser workman never any saw.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yea yonder sits the wonder of mine eye;
I have not been the first whom destiny
Hath thwarted thus; imperious love,
Either withdraw the shaft that wounds my heart,
Or grant me patience to endure my smart:
Remorseless love, had any but thyself
Been privy to my direful passion,
How I consume and waste myself in love,
They would have been, yea much more pitiful:
But all avails not; demanding for my work
Shall be a means to have some conference.
Good morrow to you, is my handkercher done?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Yea mistress flower, it is finished.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How sweetly tunes the accent of his voice!
O, do not blame me, dearest love alive,
Though thus I dote in my affection;
I toil, I labour, and I fain would thrive,
And thrive I may if thou wouldst give direction:
Thou art the star whereby my course is led,
Be gracious then, bright sun, or I am dead.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Fair mistress Phillis, such wanton toys as these,
Are for young novices that will soon be pleased,
The careful thoughts that hammer in my brain,
Bid me abandon wanton love; 'tis vain.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For me it is.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Is my ungarnished, dark, and obscure cell,
A mansion fit for all-commanding love?
No, if thou wilt sport with love,
And dally with that wanton amorous boy;
Hie thee unto the odoriferous groves.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: There is no groves more pleasant unto me,
than to be still in thy society.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: There of the choicest fragrant flowers that grow
Thou mayst devise sweet roseate coronets,
And with the nymphs that haunt the silver streams,
Learn to entice the affable young wag;
There shalt thou find him wand ring up and down,
Till some fair saint impale him with a crown:
Be gone I say, and do not trouble me,
For to be short, I cannot fancy thee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For to be short, you cannot fancy me:
O cruel word, more hateful than pale death,
O, would to God it would conclude my breath.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Forbear, forbear, admit that I should yield:
Think you, your father would applaud your choice.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Doubt not thereof, or if he do not, all's one,
So you but grant to my affection.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: I am too base.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My wealth shall raise thee up.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: I am deformed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Tut, I will bear with that.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Your friend's dislike brings all this out of frame.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By humble suit I will redress the same.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Now to employ the virtue of my shape:
Fair mistress,
If heretofore I have remorseless been,
And not esteemed your undeserved love,
Whereby in the glass of your affection
I see my great unkindness; forgive what's passed,
And here I proffer all the humble service
Your high prized love doth merit at my hands,
Which I confess is more than I unable
Can gratify: therefore command my toil,
My travel, yea, my life to pleasure you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I take thee at thy word, proud of thy service,
But yet no servant shalt thou be of mine,
I will serve thee, command, and I'll obey:
This doth my soul more good, yea, ten times more
Than did thy harsh denial harm before,
Let us embrace like two united friends,
Here love begins, and former hatred ends.

div.stage: Enter Ferdinand and Anthony walking together.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Brother Anthony, what news from Venice?
Are your ships returned? I had ratherAside.
Hear news from Phillis: o, brother Frank,
Thy absence makes me burn in passion.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Sir, I had letters from my factors there
Some three days since; but the return of one,Aside.
Of one poor letter, yet not answered,
Makes me stark mad: a plague upon that porter,
Damned may he be for thus deluding me.
sp.stage: Ferdinand spies Phillis and turns back.
sp.l: How now brother, why retire you so?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Yonder's a friend of mine acquaintance,
With whom I would gladly have some conference,
I pray thee stay I will return immediately.

div.stage: Go to Phillis and court her to themselves.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Of your acquaintance; is she so good brother?
Only with you acquainted, and no other?
Faith I'll try that, take heed sir what you do.
If you begin to court, I needs must woe,Go to her too.
Brother have you done?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: But two words more at most:
You have not then received any such letter?
A vengeance take the lazy messenger;
Brother if I live, I'll quittance thee for this,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Good words, dear brother, threatened men live long.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: You have done.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Then by your leave brother,
You had one word, I must have another. Talk in private.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I know our business tends to one effect:
Oh that villain Frank, it mads my soul
I am so wronged, by such a foolish boy.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: That foolish boy may chance prove to be witty:
What, and the elder brother's fools? O 'tis pity!

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: That villain porter hath deluded me,
Confusion guerdon his base villain.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: What are you cursing too? than we catch no fish:
Comes there any more, here's two snights to a dish.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Well, since I have such opportunity,
I'll trust no longer to uncertainty.

div.stage: He courts her again in private.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: At it so hard brother; well, woe apace,
A while I am content to give you place.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Well, to her both, both do the best you can;
I fear young Frank will prove the happier man.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You have your answer, trouble me no more.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yet this is worse than my suspense before,
For then I lived in hope, now hope is fled.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: What, male content? is Ferdinand struck dead,
Fortune be blithe, and aid the second brother.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Think you to have more favour than another?
To her a god's name, live not in suspense,
While you two strive, I needs must get the wench.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am resolved, and, sir you know my mind.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: What, you repulsed too? Phillis is too unkind.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Here sits my love, within whose lovely breast
Lives my content, and all my pleasure's rest,
And for a further confirmation,
Which to approve, even in sight of both you here present,
I give my hand, and with my hand, my heart,
Myself, and all to him; and with this ring
I'll wed myself.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I take thy offering,
And for the gift you gave to me, take this,
And let us seal affection with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: O sight intolerable.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: A spectacle worse than death.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Now gentlemen, please you draw near and listen to the cripple.
sp.stage: Give them the letters and they stamp and storm.
sp.l: Know you that letter? sir, what say you to this?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: How came they to your hands?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Sirs, a porter even of late left them with me,
To be delivered to this gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: A plague upon that porter; if ere I meet him,
my rapiers point with a death's wound shall greet him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Frank thou art a villain, thou shalt know't ere long.
For proffering me such undeserved wrong. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: So, vomit forth the rheum of all your spite,
These threats of yours procure me more delight.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now gentle love, all that I have to say,
Is to entreat you seek without delay,
My father's kind consent, for thou hast mine,
And though he storm yet will I still be thine;
Make trial then, 'tis but thy labour lost,
Though he deny thee, it requires no cost.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I will assail with expedition.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: God, and good fortune go with thee, farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Well, I will go, but not in this disguise;
Arm thee with policy Frank, Frank must be wise:
Now would the substance of this borrowed shape
Were here in presence, and see where he comes,
Poor in the well framed limbs of nature, but
Rich in kindness beyond comparison.
Welcome dear friend, the kindest soul alive,
Here I resign thy habit back again,
Whereby I prove the happiest man that breathes.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Hast thou then, sweet blood, been fortunate?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Hark, I will tell thee all:Whisper in private.

div.stage: Enter Bowdler, Mall Berry, and Ralfe, Bowdler capers and sings.

sp.speaker: Ralf.
sp.l: Faith sir, methinks of late you are very light.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: As a feather, sweet rogue, as a feather:
Have I not good cause, sweet mall, sweet mall,
Hath she not caused the same: well, if I live, sweet wench,
Either by night or day I will requite your kindness.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Now I will take my leave, to put the same in practice. Exit Frank.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Good fortune wait on thee.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Mall, thou art mine, by thine own consent;
How sayest thou Mall?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ralfe.
sp.l: I am witness sir.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: But that is not sufficient mall, if thou art content mall, here's a rogue hard by, a friend of mine, whom I will acquaint with our loves, and he shall be partaker of the match.

sp.speaker: Ralf.
sp.l: Nay sir, if you mean to have partners in the match, I hope Ralfe can help to serve your wife's turn as well as another, whate'er he be. How say you mistress?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: All's one to me, whom he please.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Come then sweet mall, we'll to the drawer,
There to dispatch what I further intend.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: And well remembered husband.

sp.speaker: Ralfe.
sp.l: A forward maiden by this light; husband before the clerk hath said amen.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: He hath work of mine, I pray forget it not.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: I will not Mall. Now you lame rogue, where is this maiden's work? my wife's work you rascal, quick, give it her?

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Sweet signior, the sweet nymph's work is almost finished, but sweet blood, you drive me into admiration with your latter words, your sweet wife's work, I admire it!

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: I ye halting rascal, my wife's work; she's my wife before God and Ralfe, how sayest thou Mall, art thou not?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yes for sooth, and to confirm the same,
Here in this presence, I plight my faith again;
And speak again, what erst before was said,
That none but you shall have my maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: A good wench Mall, i'faith, now will I to thy father for his good will, Cripple, see you remember what is past, for I will call thee in question for a witness if need require, farewell cur, farewell dog. Exit. Bowdler and Ralfe.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: A due fond humorist, parenthesis of jests,
Whose humour like a needless cypher fills a room:
But now Mall Berry, a word or two with you:
Hast thou forgotten Barnet? thy thoughts were bent on him.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: On him Cripple! for what? was it for marriage?

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: It was for love, why not for marriage? O monstrous!
Were I a maid and should be so bewitched,
I'd pull my eyes out that did lend me light,
exclaim against my fortune, ban my stars,
And tear my heart, so yielding her consent
To Bowdler's love, that froth of compliment.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Cripple, you lose your time, with your fair tears
To circumvent my heart: Bowdler I love thee,
Barnard I hate, and thou shalt never move me.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: I will; thou dost love Barnard, and I can prove it.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: That I love Barnard! by heavens I abhor him.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Thou lovest him, once again I say, thou lovest him,
For all thou hast born Bowdler still in hand.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: What wilt thou make me mad? I say, I hate him.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: I say thou lovest him: have not I been at home,
And heard thee in thy chamber praise his person,
And say he is a proper little man,
And pray that he would be a suitor to thee?
Have I not seen thee in the bay-window
To sit cross-armed, take counsel of thy glass,
And prune thyself to please young Barnard's eye?
Some times curling thy hair, then practising smiles,
Sometimes rubbing thy filthy butter-teeth,
Then pull the hairs from off thy beetle-brows.
Painting the veins upon thy breasts with blue,
An hundred other tricks I saw thee use,
And all for Barnard.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: For Barnard! 'twas for Bowdler.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: I say, for Barnard.
Nay more, thou knowest I lay one night at home,
And in thy sleep I heard thee call on Barnard
Twenty times over.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Will you be sworn I did.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Ay, I will swear it:
And art thou not ashamed thus to be changed,
To leave the love of a kind gentleman
To dote on Bowdler? Fie, fie, reclaim thyself:
Embrace thy Barnard, take him for thy husband,
And save his credit, who is else undone,
By thy hard father's hateful cruelty.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Cripple, if thou canst prove that ever I
did fancy Barnard, I will love him still.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Why I'll be sworn thou didst.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: And that I doted on him in my sleep.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: I'll be sworn I could not sleep all night
In the next room, thou didst so rave on him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I cannot tell, I may well be deceived,
I think I might affect him in my sleep,
And yet not know it; let me look on him,
I'faith he is a pretty handsome fellow,
'Tis pity he should waste himself in prison;
Heigh ho.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: What's the matter wench?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Cripple, I will love him.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Wilt thou i'faith?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I'faith I will. Enter two sergeants

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Give me thy hand, a bargain, 'tis enough.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But how shall he know I love him?

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Why thus: I will entreat the sergeants
To go with him along unto thy father,
And by the way I'll send young Bowdler from us,
And then acquaint my Barnard with thy love,
He shall accept it and avouch the same
Unto thy father, wench do thou the like,
And then I hope his bonds are cancelled.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: Cripple, shall we have your company?

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: My friends, hold here, there's money for your pains
Walk with your prisoner but to master Berry,
And ye shall either find sufficient bail,
Or else discharge the debt, or I assure you
We'll be your aid to guard him safe to prison.

sp.speaker: 1. sergeant
sp.l: Well, we are willing sir, we are content
To show the gentleman any kind of favour.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Along then; hark master Bowdler. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter master Flower, mistress Flower, master Berry, and Fiddle.

sp.speaker: Mayst Flo.
sp.l: Welcome good master Berry, is your stomach up sir? It is a good conceit i'faith.

sp.speaker: Fiddle
sp.l: It is indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: What, fiddle!

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: If his stomach be up to go to dinner.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Fiddle, bid master Berry welcome.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: What else master? with the best belly in my heart, the sweetest strain in my music, and the worst entertainment that may be, fiddle bids your worship adesdum.

sp.speaker: Berry
sp.l: Thanks fiddle, and master flower, I am much beholding to your courtesy.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Fiddle, I wonder that he stays so long,
Thou toldst me Anthony would follow thee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ay, and he'll be here I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: I'll tell you sir, it is a rare conceit,
My wife would have her marry Anthony,
The younger brother, but against her mind,
I will contract her unto Ferdinand,
And I have sent for you and other friends,
To witness it; and 'tis a good conceit.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Fiddle, are all things ordered well within?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: All's well, all's well, but there wants some saffron,
To colour the custards withal.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Here, take my keys, bid Susan take enough.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Fiddle, are all our guests come yet?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ay sir, and here comes one more than you looked for.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: God save you master flower, as much to you master Berry.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Welcome m. Golding, you're very welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: My brother Ferdinand commends him to you,
And here's a letter to you from himself.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: A letter sir, it is a good conceit,
I'll read it straight,
sp.stage: Gives the other letter to mistress Flower.
sp.l: Master flower, I am beholding to you for your kindness, and your furtherance in my love-suit, but my mind is changed, and I will not marry your daughter, and so farewell.
This is no good conceit: what Ferdinand,
Delude old flower, make me deceive my friends,
make my wife laugh, and triumph in her will,
What think you fiddle?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Why sir I think it is no good conceit.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Thou sayest true fiddle, 'tis a bad conceit,
But hear you sir.

body.p: I understand by fiddle your forwardness in my suit to your daughter: but nevertheless I am determined to draw back, and commit your daughter to her best fortunes, and yourself to God; farewell.

sp.l: Why this is like my husband's bad conceit,
Have you o'erreached me flower, you crafty fox?
This is your doing, but for all your sleight
I'll cross you if my purpose hit aright.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Tut, tell not me sir, for my credit and reputation is as it is, and there's an end: if I shall have her, why so.

sp.speaker: Maist. Flo.
sp.l: Sir, the conceit is doubtful, give me leave but to consider of it by myself.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Master Golding, a word I pray sir,
You know my daughter Phillis, do you not?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Mistress, I do.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: She is a star I tell you.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: She is no less indeed.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: I tell you sir upon the sudden now,
There came an odd conceit into my head,
Are you a bachelor?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: I am indeed.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: And are you not promised?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Not yet believe me.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Master Golding.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Well, do you hear sir? if you will be pleased
To wed my daughter Phillis, you shall have her.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: To wed your daughter, why she loves me not.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: All's one for that, she will be ruled by me:
Disdain her not because I proffer her,
I tell you sir, merchants of great account
Have sought her love, and gentlemen of worth,
Have humbly sued to me in that behalf:
to say the truth, I promised her to one,
But I am crossed and thwarted by my husband,
Who means to marry her unto another:
Now sir, to cry but quittance for his guile,
I offer her to you; if you accept her,
I'll make her dowry richer by a pair
Of hundred pounds than else it should have been.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Why this is excellent, passed all compare,
Sued to to have her, gentle mistress flower,
Let me consider of it.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Nay, nay, defer no time if you will have her,
I'll search my coffers for another hundred.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Say I should yield, your husband will withstand it.

sp.speaker: Mistress Fl.
sp.l: I'll have it closely done without his knowledge;
Is it a match?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Well, well, I am content.

sp.speaker: Mast. Fl.
sp.l: Why then old flower, I'll cross your close intent.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: It shall be so; and 'tis a good conceit,
It shall be so if but to cross my wife,
Hark master Golding, the conceit doth like me.
You love my daughter, so methought you said;
You said moreover, that she loves you well,
This love on both sides is a good conceit.
But are you sure sir, that my daughter loves you?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: For proof thereof show her this ring.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: A ring of hers! 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: I but conceit me,
If I had wood her in my proper shape,
I do believe she never would have liked me,
Therefore since I shall have her, give me leave
To come and court her in my borrowed shape.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: With all my heart, and 'tis a good conceit,
And here's my hand, son Golding, thou shalt have her.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Then father flower, I rest upon your promise,
I'll leave you for a while, till I put on
My counterfeited shape, and then return. Exit.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Welcome good son, 'tis well, by this conceit
My wife will be prevented of her will:
I would not for the half of all my wealth,
My cross-word wife had compassed her intent:
Now wife.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Now husband.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: You still maintain the suit for Anthony,
You'll have your will, and I must break my word.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Jest on old flower, be cross, and do thy worst,
Work the best means thou canst, yet whiles I live
I swear she never shall wed Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Mast. Flo.
sp.l: What shall she not?

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: No that she shall not.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: I say, she shall.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: I'faith she shall not.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: No!

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Well wife, I am vexed, and by God's precious.

sp.speaker: Master Berry
sp.l: O sir, be patient gentle mistress flower,
Cross not your husband, let him have his will.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: His will!

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Hearst thou wife, be quiet, thou knowest my humour.
Thus to be crossed, it is no good conceit.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: A fig for your conceit; yet for because,
I know I shall prevent him of the match,
That he intends, henceforth I will dissemble.
Well master flower, because it shall be said,
And for kind master Berry may report
The humble loyalty I bear to you,
Such as a wife should do unto her husband.
I am content to yield to your desires,
Protesting, whiles I live, I never more
Will speak that Anthony may marry her.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Wife, speakst thou with thy heart?

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Husband, I do.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Dost thou indeed?

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: Indeed forsooth I do.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Then 'tis a good conceit: ha, ha;
I see 'tis sometimes good to look aloft,
Come hither wife, because thou art so humble,
I'll tell thee all, I have received a letter
From Ferdinand, wherein he sends me word,
He will not marry with my daughter Phillis,
And therefore I was full determined
To cross thy purpose, that his brother Frank
Should marry her, and so I still intend:
What sayest thou wife, dost thou assent thereto?

sp.speaker: Mistress Flo.
sp.l: That Frank should marry her, I have sworn he shall,
And since this falls so right, I'll not disclose,
That I did mean so much; but now I'll yield,
That it may seem my true humility:
Husband, because hereafter you may say,
And think me loving, loyal, and submiss,
I am content, Frank shall have my consent.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Why now thou showst thyself obedient,
And thou dost please me with thy good conceit.

div.stage: Enter Barnard, Mall, and two sergeants.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: By your leave master flower,
Berry I am arrested at your suit.

sp.speaker: Berry
sp.l: And I am glad of it with all my heart;
Hold friends, there's somewhat more for you to drink,
Away with him to prison.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: Stay master Berry, I have brought you bail.

sp.speaker: Berry
sp.l: What bail? where is your bail? here's none I know
Will be thy bail, away with him to prison.

sp.speaker: Mall
sp.l: Yes, I forsooth father, I'll be his bail,
Body for body; think you I'll stay at home,
And see my husband carried to the jail?

sp.speaker: Berry
sp.l: How, thy husband!

sp.speaker: Mall
sp.l: My husband I assure you:
Father, these sergeants both can witness it.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: We saw them both contracted man and wife,
And therefore thought it fit to give you knowledge,
Before we carried him unto the prison.

sp.speaker: Berry
sp.l: But I'll undo this contract on my blessing,
Daughter, come from him, he's a reprobate.

sp.speaker: Mall
sp.l: He is my husband.

sp.speaker: Berry
sp.l: But thou shalt not have him.

sp.speaker: Mall
sp.l: Faith but I will, Barnard, speak for thyself.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: Why m. Berry, 'tis well known to you,
I am a gentleman, though by misfortune,
My ventures in the world have somewhat failed me:
Say that my wealth disables my desert,
The difference of our bload supplies that want?
What though my lands be mortgaged, if you please,
The dowry you intend to give your daughter,
May well redeem them. You perhaps imagine
I will be wild, but I intend it not.
What shall I say, if you will give consent?
As you redeem my lands, so I my time ill spent
Mean to redeem; with frugal industry,
I'll be your counsel's pupil, and submit
My follies to your will, mine to your wit.

sp.speaker: Berry
sp.l: What think you master flower?

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Faith master Berry,
Barnara speaks well, and with a good conceit.

sp.speaker: Mal
sp.l: Dost thou love him Mall?

sp.speaker: Mall
sp.l: Yes sir, and here protest,
Of all in London I love Barnard best.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Then master Berry, follow my conceit,
Cancel his bond, and let him have your daughter.

sp.speaker: Berry
sp.l: Well Barnard, since I see my daughter loves thee,
And for I hope thou wilt be kind and loving,
Regard thy state, and turn an honest man,
Here, take my daughter, I'll give thee in thy bond,
Redeem thy lands, and if thou please me well,
Thou shalt not want all that I have is thine.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: I am love-bound to her, to you in duty,
You conquer me with kindness, she with beauty.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: Then master Berry I think we may depart.

sp.speaker: Berry
sp.l: Ay, when you please, you see the matter ended,
The debt discharged, and I can ask no more.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: Why then we take our leaves. Exeunt sergeants.

sp.speaker: Ma. Flo.
sp.l: Now wife, if young Frank Golding were come back,
To sum our wish, it were a good conceit:Enter Phi.
Why how now Phillis, sad, come tell me wench,
art thou resolved yet for to have thy husband?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: A golden Golding, 'tis a good conceit.
That golden Golding is but loath some dross,
Nor is it gold that I so much esteem;
Dust is the richest treasure that we have,
Nor is the beauty of the fairest one,
Of higher price or value unto me,
Than is a lump of poor deformity.
Father, you know my mind, and what I said,
Which if you grant not, I will rest a maid. Enter Fid.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: To die a maid, that is no good conceit.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Master, where's my master? here's one would couple a brace of words with you.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: With me sir.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: No sir, with my young mistress.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: What is he knave?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: A crooked knave sir, 'tis the cripple.

sp.speaker: Mai. Flo.
sp.l: What would he have? he hath no good conceit,
'Tis he that hath bewitched my daughter's heart,
He is a knave, go send him packing hence.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: As you respect the welfare of your child,
Dear father, let me speak with him.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Speak with him! no, it is no good conceit,
I know he comes to run away with thee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Run away with her? well may she carry him, but if he run away with her, I'll never trust crutch more.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: Thou sayest true fiddle, 'tis a good conceit:
Go call him in, Frank Golding, it is he. Exit Fid.
In the lame knave's disguise, a good conceit;Enter Frank
Now sir, what's the news with you, you come to speak with my daughter?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Yea sir, about a little work I have of hers.

sp.speaker: Master Flo.
sp.l: What work, you knave? no, thou hast some conceit, to rob me of my daughter; but away:
I like not that conceit out of my doors.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Unhappy Phillis, and unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir, I am content, I'll not move your patience.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Life of my living body, if thou go,
though not alive take me hence dead with woe. She sounds

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.l: In troth sir, you are too blame.

sp.speaker: Master Flow.
sp.l: What? is she dead? it is no good conceit.
Speak to me Phillis, oh unhappy time,
Sweet girl, dear daughter, oh my only joy,
Speak to thy father wench, in some conceit,
What, not a word?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.l: Now may you see, what fall impatience
Begets upon such tender plants as these.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flow.
sp.l: Now may we see the folly of old age,
Governed by spleen, and overweening rage.

sp.speaker: Master Flow.
sp.l: Speak to me, daughter.
And thou shalt have, what not? covetst thou gold?
Thou shalt not want for crowns, thou shalt have all.
O was my fury author of thy trance?
Did I deny thy love's access to thee?
Speak but one word and thou shalt be his wife,
By heaven thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I take you at your word; it is no pain
To die for love, and then revive again.

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.l: Now m. flower how like you this conceit,
Hath she not over reached you?

sp.speaker: M. Flow.
sp.l: My word is past, and yet for all my rage,
I rather choose to fail in my conceit,
And wed thee Phillis to thy own content.
Here, take my daughter, Cripple, love her well,
Be kind to her, and I'll be kind to thee,
Thou art but poor, well I will make thee rich,
And so God bless you, with a good conceit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I thank you, when I leave to love my wife,
Heaven hasten death and take away my life.

sp.speaker: M. Flow.
sp.l: 'Tis well done Frank, I applaud thy wit,
And now I know I fail not in conceit.

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.l: Gentlemen sweet bloods, or brothers of familiarity,
I would speak with Phillis, shall I have audience?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Help me dear father, oh help me gentlemen,
This is some spirit, drive him from my sight.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Were he the devil, thou shalt not budge a foot.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Zounds two cripples, two dogs two curs, 'tis wonderful!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Fear not dear heart.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hence foul deformity.
Nor thou nor he, shall my companion be,
If cripples dead, the living seem to haunt,
I'll neither of either, therefore I say avaunt;
Help, me father.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Dear heart, revoke these words,
Here are no spirits nor deformities,
I am a counterfeit Cripple now no more,
But young Frank Golding. as I was before:
Amaze not love, nor seem not discontent,
Nor thee nor him shall ever this repent.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: M. flower, I come to claim your promise.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I come for yours, your daughter I do mean.

sp.speaker: M. Flow.
sp.l: My promise; why sir, you refused my promise,
And sent me word so in your letter.

sp.speaker: Mistress Flow.
sp.l: And so did you to me, and now 'tis past,
Your brother Frank hath both our free consents.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Sir, sir, I wrote no letter.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: By heaven, nor I.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: But I did for you both; I was your scribe,
The whilst you went to see your house a fire:
And you (As I remember) I did send,
To see your sister drowned at London-bridge.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I'faith good brother have you o'erreached us so?

sp.speaker: Anth,
sp.l: So cunningly, that none of us could know.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: For all this cunning, I will break the match.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: And so will I.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Why brothers, she's mine by her father's gift.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Brother you lie, you got her with a shift.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I was the first that loved her.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: That's not so, was I.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Catch that catch can, than brothers both you lie.

sp.speaker: M. Flow.
sp.p:
Yea, but conceit me gentlemen, what do you
mean to spoil my daughter? you claim her, and I have given her your younger brother; this is no good conceit: why how now Phillis, still drooping, cheer thee my girl, see a company of gentlemen are at strife for thy love; look up, and in this fair assembly make thine own choice; choose where thou wilt, and use thine own conceit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But will my father then applaud my choice?

sp.speaker: M. Flow.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And will these worthy gentlemen be pleased,
However my dislike or liking prove?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We will.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I must confess you all have taken pains,
And I can give but all for that pains taken,
And all my all, is but a little love,
And of a little who can make division,
I would I knew what would content you all.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Thy love.

sp.speaker: Another
sp.l: Thy life and love.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Thy life, thy love, thyself, and all for me,
For if I want but one, I then want thee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If then I give what either if you crave,
Though not what you desire will it suffice.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I wish but love.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And as a friend you have it.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I life and love.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And as your friend, I vow, to love you whilst I live, as do now.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I ask but all for I deserve no more.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And thou shalt have thy wish, take all my store,
My love myself.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: By heaven, I ask no more:
Brothers, have done, and dad to end all strife,
Come take her hand and give her for my wife.

sp.speaker: M Flow.
sp.l: Withal my heart, and 'tis a good conceit.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Gentlemen, patience is your fairest play.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Impatience pulls me hence, for this disdain,
I am resolved never to love again. Exit.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Stay brother Ferdinand, I'll follow thee,
Farewell all love, 'tis full of treachery. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: By heaven's Frank I do commend thy wit,
Come mall, shall thou and I ask blessing too for company?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: You and I sir, alas, we are not playfellows, though we be turtles: I am provided.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Provided! why am not I thy Menelaus?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Ay sir, but this is my Paris, I am resolved,
And what I do is by authority.

sp.speaker: Bowd.
sp.l: Is it even so, is Helen stolen by Paris?
Then thus in arms will Menelaus mourn,
Till Troy be sacked, and Helena return. Exit

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: This is the man, officers attach him upon felony.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: M. flower, I arrest you upon felony, and charge you to obey.

sp.speaker: M. Flow.
sp.l: Arrest me upon felony! at whose suit?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Sir, at mine; where had you that diamond on your finger? it was stole from me, and many other jewels to the value of a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: M Flo.
sp.l: This is no good conceit; hath captain racket,
Banded old flower to such an exegent?
I hope my credit somewhat will assist me;
Well, whither must I go?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: Straight to the bench, where now the judges are
To give you speedy trial.

sp.speaker: M. Flow.
sp.l: Words here are little worth, wife and friends all
Go with me to my trial, you shall see
A good conceit now brought to infamy. Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
